Woodstock participants wallowed in Yasgar's muddy fields. [Director Ang]Lee wallows in Teichberg's muddy %u2014 and uninteresting %u2014 experience.
It's not all about Steve. And even if it was all about Steve, it still isn't a good story. Why? Steve isn't interesting. Neither is Mary Horowitz, the woman stalking Steve.
[Mike Judge] Outrageous %u2014 yes. Always. Funny? Judge is hit and miss, but more hit than miss.
The highlight is a contest of wills between three contestants of the extreme skateboarding of the Slam event. It is heavy drama worth the price of the ticket.
Kids find boogers and farts irresistible. Shorts is a kids movie for kids. Completely. Adults are welcome to come along for the ride.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Throw a dozen outrageous characters at the screen and stick them in equally shocking plots and sub-plots and see what sticks. With Inglourious Basterds everything sticks.
Told in brilliantly written non-linear clumps, it is more of a falling-out-of-love story than a traditional tale of boy-meets-girl, they struggle but live happily ever after.
The Time Traveler's Wife drags so much that you will wish you could be a time traveler and speed past the slow spots %u2014 and it's all slow spots.
...A fascinating opening hooks you completely....And then, [director Neil] Blomkamp and his cohort[co-writer Terri Tatchel] run out of original ideas.
The film is gratefully short but writer/director David Twohy still takes too much time working through the standard suspect check list before getting to a terrific twist.
9 is The Terminator on ritalin. It is loaded with adult themes but really aimed at kids. And %u2014 ironically %u2014 it is the perfect flick for a nine-year old boy.
By act three, this sentimental twaddle bounces all over the place trying to find a center. It never does. If you think that's overwritten, wait until you see the movie.
I have just one complaint. It should have been 3-D. A solid, kid-friendly story with a floating city filled with high-tech gizmos and gadgets deserves the extra dimension.
Yes %u2014 I am giving A Christmas Carol a high rating. It is technical perfection and brilliantly done. However, it is too much Zemeckis, too much Carrey. Not enough Dickens.
The Rock's stock has slipped from ex-superstar wrestler and Scorpion King and action-icon heir apparent to donning Dollar Store lace wings and a tutu to play a tooth fairy.
If you're careful and limit the soda intake, you won't leave the theater with a sugar high.
It's a grind. Each weary, rainy step is agony. Around every corner is more desolation. More destruction. More misery. On it goes until The Road finally hits a dead end.
Sometimes less is more. Nine is eight too many.
Not long into the production the words get uttered that turn a stylish, well-done, well-acted production to predictable mush. The words: "In the time before%u2026"
The Messenger makes it [the death of a soldier] personal. And it is uncomfortable. Well-done movies about the tragedy of war and its impact on ordinary lives are that way.
A late scene has Amy Adams standing at the edge of a cliff. I thought she was going to jump. Had it not been so late in the movie, I would have gladly traded her places.
Youth in Revolt? Forget that! Let's focus on critic in revolt. Even a little [Michael] Cera is too much.
To make Holmes palatable to technology addicted, everything's gotta-go-fast moviegoers throw Indiana Jones and Harry Potter themes at the screen and see what sticks.
Don't let a premise that sounds as boring as a corporate board meeting keep you from catching what may be the year's best movie.
It's Complicated isn't. This is straight-ahead, sophisticated comedy, an evolution of what Doris Day, Rock Hudson and Tony Randall did in the 1960s.
The...world-class band, the techno tricks and state-of-the-art effects, especially the Humphrey Bogart chase sequence, are stunning. It would have been a hell of a show.
Kids will love this movie and %u2014 as history teaches %u2014 they love the chipmunks. It's fast-paced, has plenty of music, a really funny fart joke and a happy-ending life lesson.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: James Cameron invented a world comparable to George Lucas' galaxy of long ago, far, far away and as original as what Peter Jackson did with J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-Earth.
Some scenes are so strained and emotions are stretched so tight that you %u2014 like the characters %u2014 want to get up and leave.
Everybody's Fine is a holiday flick about a man in crisis. It quietly wonders how someone can know his children for 30 or more years and not really know a thing about them.
Great writer/directors such as Wes Anderson prove that you don't need flash, sizzle, three-dimensions and big budgets to make a great animated feature.
Everything in Ninja Assassin is over-amped.
It works for about 20 minutes. And only if you grew up in the 1950s to juke boxes filled with rock and roll including Sheb Wooley's The Purple People Eater
Bullock adds two extra dimensions to her usual one-dimensional, cutesy, addle-brained personality and gives the performance of her life.
Vampire movies should suck but not like this. Some will want to drive a wooden stake through my heart. It's a waste of time. Ask anyone who knows me. I don't have a heart.
2012 is straight ahead smash the world to smithereens while a cadre of characters placed in soap opera situations deliver unintentionally laughable lines.
Part disturbing documentary, part straight-ahead movie-making, The Fourth Kind is difficult to watch, difficult to understand and difficult to recommend.
More movies going nowhere should be this much fun!
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Forget witness protection, with this one you need protection %u2014 'witless' protection.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Argo is a gripping, nail-biting thriller whose last act will have you sitting on the edge of your seat.
Comes from a teen-focused post apocalyptic book. They call it speculative fiction. I call it much less than a MAZE ing.
The bottom line is there are many perks to The Perks of Being a Wallflower.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Could use a trim but the push that the African American community needs to do something about gangs resonates.
Just the bare necessities.
Hank Williams drinks, makes music, gets married, drinks, makes music, fools around, drinks, gets divorced, etc. and then he dies. Kind of like this movie.
Terrorists in a house. A little girl is in the way of taking them out. Pummels you with the question is the life of the one more important than the life of the many?
The real miracle here is that I gave it a 1 rather than a zero like it deserves.
Melissa Rauch is the best low-life character since Billy Bob's Bad Santa. Not for everyone but I couldn't stop laughing.
The movie address to find this weekend is 10 Cloverfield Lane. Delightfully entertaining and John Goodman's loose cannon is among his best ever performances.
Funny in places but not really a comedy. This one gives Tina Fey a chance to show off her acting chops. She's fabulous.
Is anyone else tired of terrorist movies? Too close to home. And, worse, this is a sequel to a terrorist threatens the president movie that is just as badly done.
The motor vehicles department scene alone is worth the price of a ticket. I'm still laughing.
This one is a hoot from start to finish and is loosely based on the true story of British Olympian Eddie Edwards. Key word: loosely. Google the REAL story. It's much more fun!
Triple 9 starts slow and builds to a nail-biting intensity equal to downing a few triple lattes. And Kate Winslet is unrecognizable. How fun is that?
Alex Proyas apologized for not using actual Egyptians in Egyptian roles. Few of us care. A more important apology might be for the movie's third act.
This is like watching -- in the biblical sense -- a King James version of a horror movie. It's getting critical raves but it made me want to go home and take a shower.
Rebel Wilson is the draw for this 20 to 30-something rom-com. I'm a fan but she's awful in this one. However, the movie is awful so maybe it doesn't matter.
Fresh. Barely. Two things. Why make a sequel 15-years after the fact? Second. You do have to give a film extra credit when it manages to even make Will Ferrell funny.
Deadpool had me laughing from the clever opening credits to Ryan Reynolds' just as clever credit roll outtake. This is what Spider-man's two franchises should have been.
I don't read Nicholas Sparks books and can't say he shouldn't keep writing them. I do see the movies. I have expertise there and can say emphatically, stop making them.
An outrageous idea that could have used a better sense of humor. That said, it's better than Jane Austen which isn't saying much because it's still Jane Austen.
Ethan and Joel Coen flashback to 1950s Hollywood. It's their best film since O' Brother, Where Art Thou? and when the credits roll we all tip our hats and say Hail, Caesar.
Must've been in the right mood for teen-focused alien-invasion-end-of-the-world-movie. What will be a trilogy of movies -- or more -- is off to a better start than its peers.
The story of what happened in Benghazi. Not political. Makes no judgments. Safe for liberals. Somewhat disappointing to conservatives. Overall, too long but a good movie.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Revenant is a revenge in a dish definitely served cold.
Kevin Costner's haircut is the worst in movie history and that's criminal. Guilty pleasure for those liking the genre.
Barely fresh and mostly because of the visuals. Ironically, it's a prequel and a sequel to the so-so Snow White and the Huntsman. It's kinda fun. Key word: kinda.
Been there, done. Clooney and Roberts back and forth saves the film and makes it worth a view. But it has two negatives: Absolutely nowhere to go and zip for tension.
A clone of the original. Clones in movies are not always a good thing. And this is proof.
Even functioning at way below his golden years level, Woody Allen's writing is still terrific. This one benefits from Allen's always exceptional casting.
Absolutely Fresh: The Movie isn't. But it's not bad. Fun and funny in spots.
A teenage game of basically truth or dare is the focus. Supposed to be tense and isn't. Texting teens walking across an actual real street is much more nerve-wracking.
Matt Damon is Bourne again. Looks like all the other Bourne movies. Suspend disbelief and just enjoy the ride.
There's a lot of good in bad moms. Done by the guys who did The Hangover. Raunchy but when it's funny, it's really funny.
Won't make you want to look under the bed, in the closet or leave the lights on when you go to bed but it's not bad.
Doesn't boldly go where other Star Treks have gone, but hey, it's Star Trek so what's not to love? Fun film and the second best of the now three reboots.
A terrific nail-biter with Bryan Cranston leading exceptional performances from a very good cast. Intense times 10 and digs into places most undercover movies don't.
A large percentage of the moviegoing public is gonna hear the call and who're they gonna call? Ghostbusters.
Mike and Dave need more than wedding dates and we'll start with a plot that isn't stale, humor that isn't recycled or that's aimed at someone over the age of 15.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not much is secret. The first 20-minutes is funny and there are a few funny bits after. But you've already seen most of them in the trailers and the product push commercials.
After George Lucas put is to sleep with episodes I, II and III, the Force is definitely awake. The most fun I've had in a theater this year.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sweet movie and Steven Spielberg makes you believe that little girl is actually on the hand of a giant. Great family film in a year lacking them.
Can't resist the word play: nothing to go ape over.
Supposedly a "true" story. While debate rages, the movie is pretty good and it's an interesting view of the Civil War from people who thought everyone ought to be free.
Not a lot of intelligence - central or otherwise - but you'll laugh a lot anyway.
Kudos to Ellen. It's an Oscar-worthy performance. Finding Dory is so well-done and beautifully filmed that you forget the main characters aren't real fish and other sea life.
Hunger Games. Maze Runner. Divergent. This is how a dystopian movie ought to be made.
It's The Lord of the Rings on steroids. Shallow plot, but hey, it's based on a game so how deep can it be? Unlike some, I was able to overlook the flaws and had a good time.
Looks like every other horror movie of this ilk. I was more entertained by the stoned lady two seats down who screamed non-stop.
All effects. No substance. No fun.
Same old, tired and very worn plot line, different movie.
Few genres are more fun than a buddy movie done right. Crowe and Gosling have a blast with these characters and you get to share in the fun.
I've never played the game. Hopefully it's more fun.
In my review, I avoided the temptation to compare the movie to this year's real life election year. Barely. Of the now three, this is the best and not bad for this genre.
At the heart of In the Heart of the Sea is Moby Dick. It bored me as a book, as movies, TV shows and in some cartoons, and now Ron Howard has done the same thing.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Just hand Bryan Cranston the Oscar, the Golden Globe, etc. The acting and the story about the importance of protecting the First Amendment is the year's best movie. So far.
Zzzzzzz. Wonderful performances but do we really care about a teenager from Ireland trying to decide between guys, one on one continent, the other on another?
When Woody Allen is bad, he's really bad.
Meryl Streep is a hell of a rock singer and in a great band. What she isn't in is a great movie.
No doubt I'm not the only critic calling this the not-so-Fantastic Four. Awful beyond description.
Not as good as The Fault is in Our Stars but the producers of this one do hit a perfect teen movie note.
A movie is pretty bad when -- in this critic's opinion -- an Adam Sandler movie opening the same weekend has a higher rating.
Perfect movie for those who still have their mullets and remember playing Pac Man as the best times of their lives.
Unlike the two-dimensional pages of a comic book, and unlike it's two-dimensional Marvel Comics movie character cousins, Ant-Man is three-dimensional fun.
Decent sci-fi if it's your thing and from Tarsem Singh who is one of my favorite directors and a very good storyteller.
My 2-year old granddaughter loves minions so we made this her first theater experience. Is it memorable? Probably not. Mixed results for her. Grandpa laughed his butt off.
Why a plot? Why not just shoot Channing Tatum and co-stars dancing shirtless for an hour and let their drooling fans see them dancing? Zero magic in this Magic Mike.
The series reboot is barely fresh but Arnold, who reprises what is ironically his most human character, is fun. But like all time-involved movies, it crashes and burns.
Nothing cerebral but nothing to make you cry uncle either. Fun fluff and the throwback to the 60s is a nice touch. Too bad you never quite believe you're there.
Inside Out is what a "kids" movie ought to be. And what adult can't relate to what happens to Riley? All of us have been there, maybe not that way, but there nonetheless.
Mid-movie Dwayne Johnson's Ray is told if he can't save his daughter no one can. He saves her but can't save the movie. A disaster of a disaster movie.
Tomorrowland is a poorly executed great idea. Funny always makes these movies click. The humor in this one fails miserably.
The music is fabulous. The plot is silly on a grand scale. If Pitch Perfect 2 was a baseball game, this one missed the plate completely and is low, outside and in the dirt.
Director George Miller wastes enough bombs and ammunition to win a small war but it's in a winning cause. This is a lot of fun and pure guilty post-apocalyptic pleasure.
Though Sofia Vergara is definitely hot, Hot Pursuit -- in hot pursuit of your box office bucks -- is anything but hot and not worth the pursuit, hot or otherwise.
Formula flick. Period. High tech, high voltage action followed by long stretches of boring dialogue before more high tech, high voltage action. It's too long by 20-minutes.
Blake Lively is lively in this original with nowhere to go love story. Not much else is.
The worst Nicholas Sparks novel turned movie of them all. But I said that about Dear John, The Lucky One, Safe Haven and The Best of Me. This time I really mean it.
Suspension of disbelief is a must and watching Paul Walker in his last movie is like watching a ghost. It's uncomfortable at times.
It's not home sweet home but Home is a pretty good family flick and it's short and tight enough to keep young kids from squirming in their seats.
It's hard to find anything remotely funny or fun about Get Hard.
Cameron Crowe throws every love story trick possible at the screen and nothing sticks. Say aloha - as in goodbye - to Aloha.
Suicide by movie for some soon-to-be A-list actors and for Will Smith who used to be one.
The temptation to rap my way through the review was -- fortunately -- resistible. This movie, however, is not. Great piece of work whether you're into hip hop or not.
Halfway through and I'm looking for my own escape.
The 7th Rocky movie looks pretty much like all the rest but it's so much fun and always a real treat to see Sly Stallone do his most famous character.
A worn out concept has been done about 75 times. Most are bottom-feeder bad and this one is close to the bottom of the bottom feeders. Worst movie of the year so far.
An underwhelming plot is overwhelmed by an incredible mix of animation and gorgeous, real-life cinematography and movie locations.
Simply put, one of the best -- if not THE best -- movies of the year.
The remake of the 2009 Argentinian thriller isn't as good. Thanks to great performances and a terrific premise, it's a nice alternative to standing in line for Mockingjay.
Proof this should have been one, long, three-hour movie. For a movie series ending, this one moves very, very slowly and almost sleepily toward a not so interesting climax.
Fumbles the opening kickoff and never recovers. Manages a field goal at the end but no touchdown.
It's 33 minutes too long and does a poor job of mining anything interesting out of this very emotional and heartwarming story.
Barely fresh. I liked the Coopers but didn't love them. Until it gets to the deadly dumb and predictable Christmas dinner, it wasn't bad. Great mix of music, too.
Charles M. Schulz would have loved this one. It's a terrific tribute to him, his characters and his fans. The Tolstoy bit had me laughing out loud. Don't miss this one.
I'm in the minority but Bond 24 looks like Bond 23, Bond 22, Bond ... etc. And it wastes Christoph Waltz who could have given us a villain as good as Gert Frobe's Goldfinger.
Moves in chunks like a video game but clocks in at a perfect movie length of 90-minutes. Rupert Friend has enough fun with the part to warrant a positive review.
The Dan Rather biopic is really more about Mary Mapes whose basic journalism failure cost both of them their jobs. It's called Truth. Not so sure that's an accurate title.
Cooking movies always inspire me to want to cook. This one didn't. It's not bad but it's not up to my cooking movie standards. Promises steak and delivers a burger.
I know I'm in the minority about Bill Murray's talent. He's just not funny and this is the least funny work he's done in a career full of not funny movies.
It's as dumb and bad as it sounds.
Best everything is written all over this one and if there is an actor working today better than Michael Fassbender, I don't know who it is.
This is Spielberg's best movie since Saving Private Ryan. The Coen Brothers may have something to do with that. And hand Mark Rylance the best supporting actor Oscar.
The most fun I've had in a theater this year.
Mars may not be such a fun place to be stranded but getting stuck in a theater watching this movie about being stuck there is.
Tedious on a grand scale but these days what war on drugs movie isn't?
Fresh. Barely. Better than the original but there's very little fire and what does burn isn't that original. Maybe that's why the scorch title is such a perfect fit.
Johnny Depp as a villain works for me. Not much else he does comes close to being as good as when he's a bad guy. Based on a true story, this is intense and Depp is brilliant.
Some will find parts of this offensive. Grow a sense of humor. I recommend hiking to a local theater and catching this really funny old guy buddy flick.
Must be political week at the movies. This, like Truth, is a political movie only it's set in Bolivia and is true but it isn't. Gives Sandra Bullock an acting stretch.
Nothing like the original. No music thankfully. Manipulative and if you're emotional or taking kids, it's a two hanky movie. Kids might like it. Adults will be bored.
Fun movie. In real life Meryl Streep is a great singer and it takes a great singer to sing this badly. Wonderful work by Hugh Grant and The Big Bang Theory's Simon Helberg.
Well done comedy focusing on the irony of a government that bans weapons business with some countries and then with a nod and a wink looks the other way when it happens.
Other critics are raving about this one. Did we see a different movie? This one is terribly disjointed and you are never connected to the characters. Wanted to like it but...
It takes two charismatic actors who have as much fun doing this as you'll have seeing it and sticks them into slam-bang action, gobs of good humor and the eye candy of an effects feast.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Best Spider-Man ever. Maguire so-so, Garfield too dark. Holland's SM is brash & funny as hell like the original comic. Well done. Most fun I've had in a theater all year.
Baby Driver is a nice twist on an old car chase, car crash, bullets flying everywhere and hitting everyone but the main characters genre. Fun flick.
To much of brothers Gru and Dru and the Bratt villain and not enough minions. It's the minions that make the franchise fun and worth seeing.
Rough language and a silly, predictable plot ruin this one in a hurry. Not funny at all.
Pick a description: sputters and stalls, runs out of gas, starts out with four flats, name one, the list is endless.
A feel good dog movie about canine solider and her handler. Dog lovers, bring a hanky. Or two.
Not really sure - even after seeing the movie - what "it" is and why it comes at night. Low budget boring.
Tom Cruise doesn't strike me as horror movie star. As if to prove the premise, he's in a horror movie that isn't that good. Needs a sense of humor & Cruise doesn't have one.
The R rating is a hard R. The very blue humor that makes total fun of the old TV series and its stars makes Baywatch worth bay watching.
Matthew McConaughey is not "awright, awright, awright" as the film's villain and this is about as exciting as a Sesame Street episode.
Fresh. barely. Johnny Depp's now dull, bumbling, mumbling & stumbling Jack Sparrow drives you to the film. His ship sailed long ago. Only the amazing effects make this work.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An Alien movie so you pretty much know how it goes. Characters sleepwalk to their doom in a dark, alien landscape. Michael Fassbender's performance makes this one worth it.
Amy Schumer steals this movie and her performance is perfect. The movie is not and Snatched manages to snatch victory out of the jaws of defeat.
Didn't hate this but everything in the movie is magical including Arthur. The movie -- alas -- is not. Message to Guy Ritchie. Go back to doing stuff like Lock, Stock.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The most fun I've had in a theater this year and as much fun as the original. This is the kind of fun that made me love movies as a kid and is why I keep reviewing film.
Promises much. Delivers little. The predictable love triangle implodes big time.
A Quentin Tarantinoesque 90 minutes shootout is a hoot. This year's best guilty pleasure movie.
Fun if you're a fan but all that's changed since the 2001 original is a few characters, more humor, bigger stunts, the death of Paul Walker and a longer run time.
It's a treat -- no matter what age you are -- to watch these old pros in action. They are among the best of their generation. And if you want to get technical, of any generation.
Can't make up its mind if its a kids movie or an adult movie kids might like and as a result, it's so-so.
The effects are fascinating for half an hour. The story is fascinating for like 5-minutes.
For a movie titled Life this one has very little of it. Pretty much the usual alien gobbling up humans in their order of importance to the plot.
An original -- surprise -- teen romance concept that fails spectacularly at the climax. Terrific performances from two young actors are all that make this worth it.
Beautiful movie beautifully done. This is stunning and MUST be seen on the big screen and not your small TV. In fact, the bigger the screen, the better and 3D if possible.
At times when you want to jump out of your seat and yell stop at the police. Brilliantly done work -- again -- by director Kathryn Bigelow.
The best heist film in years.
This one worked for me but it won't work for everyone. For an R-rating it's pretty sanitized. Call it Quentin Tarantino light.
Too much time. Not enough wrinkles. Director Ava DuVernay wants me to imagine being 12 again. The 12-year old in me didn't like it and 12-year olds today won't either.
This is a very, very difficult documentary. It is also a very, very important documentary and one I encourage everyone to see.
Eastwood's experiment casting the 3 guys as themselves just works in places. The climax, however, is worth the price of the ticket & makes you want to stand & salute.
My NYE resolution is to be more positive. I found something positive to say about Fifty Shades Freed. We're finally done with this crap and that is a positive. Right?
No surprises here, just guilty pleasure entertainment.
Whatever you call it, first time director Lawrence Sher's film is sometimes funny.
The Last Jedi should be the last Jedi. My interest died along with Hans Solo who took with him that cowboys in space humor that made the franchise so special.
A movie that is as rambling and shambling and that has just about as much focus as its main character.
Another creative Pixar/Disney character and critter movie. Never had the Land of the Dead had more life.
Wonder is a wonder and a wonderful movie about an ugly duckling turned swan. Beautifully done. Take a hanky. Or two.
Ignore the overall negative RT splat. This is guilty pleasure & a buddy flick destined to rank with Lethal Weapon, Bev Hills Cop & its cousins. Ryan and Jackson are a blast.
Finally. A D.C. comics movie with a sense of humor. Not even Affleck's boring Batman or Cavill's less than super Superman are able to ruin this one.
To his credit, director Ashutosh Gowariker's movie is beautiful and you'll fall in love with the characters.
A Watergate burglary story and its aftermath deserves a better telling than this.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Barely recommend this one. Inspiring story. A terrific performance from Claire Foy but this one falls flat when wrapping up the man's life.
Several great actors wasted. A boring villain. Too many characters in an equally boring plot. This one melts as quickly as a snowman in a heatwave.
Chan's acting and that of Brosnan is a great change of pace in a film that's a nice change of pace from the average action-thriller.
Barely Fresh. Fun the first hour and deadly dull the second. Judi Dench's Queen Victoria saves the film. However, she could play a lamp post and get award nominations.
Barely fresh. At 2:43 it's too long. Director Dennis Villeneuve is too in love with his effects and drags out his movie by half an hour. Not Blade Runner but blade crawler.
If you get a friend request to see this Friend Request. Ignore it, delete it, and run. Awful film packed with cliche horror movie characters, events & all.
The direction of spy-movie making that James Bond shoulda taken. This one is a blast. And I can't rave enough about Julianne Moore who is one of the best spy villains ever.
Fresh barely and based more on peripheral character chemistry than that of the main characters.
Wordplay from all kinds of irresistible angles comes to mind. It isn't all that scary and It is a little too long but considering horror fare these days, It is pretty good.
A-list actors have a blast with this material It is a bit slow to be of the express variety but this train is definitely worth catching.
Ironically teens aren't playing post apocalyptic teen angst trauma characters in this teen angst trauma post apocalyptic, pathetic, practically pointless movie.
Guilty pleasure with two dimensional characters in an equally two dimensional plot that only allows them to be in peril. No beauty and the beast and that's good.
I don't like Christian movies but this is a good one. Best Christian movie ever.
Decent sci-fi that wanders a bit and is kinda slow but it's darkness helps keep your interest and while good but not great, it at least is not dead on arrival.
Inferno has two good acts but with nowhere to go, the plot implodes in the third act and the whole thing bursts into flames.
Looks pretty much like every other comedy spy movie and in its own way is kinda keeping up with the Joneses.
Did anyone suspect the underwear dancing guy in Risky Business in 1983 would end up an action hero? No. Some of us still don't think he's much of one. Jack Reacher is proof.
The plot twist helps it add up. Barely.
I hate reviewing movies about slavery. Writer, director Star Nate Parker has bright future. This is a good movie but it has warts from some slight historical modifications.
This conductor says get off the train. Your stop this weekend is The Girl on the Train. A terrific whodunnit-thriller that features the year's best acting so far.
Tim Burton's mind is as peculiar as can be and usually that works. This time it doesn't. He packs this movie with superb effects but in the end it's Harry Potter light.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Deep subject. Shallow movie and such a waste of great action movie actors.
Watching chess is like watching grass grow. But this movie is so inspiring it doesn't matter.
Storks delivers.
J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter prequel is more fun than the films made from those books. Fun. Yes. But it's not exactly magical.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Magnificent Seven isn't. But it's a western and I love westerns so it gets enough points to recommend.
Awful on an epic scale.
It's been 12-years since we've seen Bridget Jones. Is 12-years long enough? Sacharine sweet for those needing a chick flick sugar fix. The rest of us will need to chew NoDoz.
Edward Snowden revealed the U.S. spy secrets and embarrassed the government. This mostly true tattle tale story leans left but is conservative safe.
Even kids won't be wild about The Wild Life.
Normally I like succinct but Clint Eastwood's 95 minute story of the miracle on the Hudson -- while a great movie -- jets through material that demands a bit more detail.
A horror slash sci-fi movie of the been-there-done-that variety. Predictable. Boring.
Billed as a romance, it is not a very good one in spite of a somewhat original story. Eventually it turns into a soap opera and has nowhere unpredictable to go.
Won't have you holding your breath. It has a villain unique enough to separate it from others of its ilk. BTW, the less you know about it before buying a ticket, the better.
One of the year's best. See this one come hell or high water.
Wonderful fantasy packed with stunning stop-motion visuals. Fun and funny for adults but a bit mature for some younger children.
The original runs 3 1/2 hours. This one is two. It's a Cliffs Notes version of one of the best movie stories ever. This one has no heart. A better title is Ben-Hurried.
Krasinski is not a bad storyteller. His movie is charming and light most of the time but heavy when needed. And most of the time it's even somewhat realistic.
The best superhero movie ever is more about the curse of super powers than super powers. Maybe that's why it's the best superhero movie ever.
Brilliantly written. Hailee Steinfeld babbles at 190 words per minute with gusts up to 220. She's amazing as is Woody Harrelson who's the recipient of most of the dialogue.
Another traditional Disney animated flick packed with wonderful effects and Broadway-worthy music. Perfect for kids, adults and -- best of all -- families.
Not rocket science or much of a rocker. There are plenty of laughs and that's especially true if you know anything about sheep. A great cast has a lot of fun with this one.
The movie says keeping monsters out is one of the legends of purpose of the Great Wall. Don't Google, you won't find it. Not close to rocket science but fun if it's your thing.
An original horror movie in an era when the genre has grown anemic. A bit too long is the only criticism.
A completely stupid movie even by this genre's low standards.
As stupid as it sounds but in these tense political times, a little stupid goes a long way.
This week's guilty pleasure.
The misleading title of the year. Even when it tries to be funny it is not. The plot about an unhappy comedian unhappily wastes an all-star cast.
Not as bad as I thought it would be but this aimed at team romance about a kid from Mars is tedious on this or any other planet.
You've heard of the dog abuse controversy. Whether it's true or not, this movie has bigger problems like a plot that's a lot of bark and not much bite.
M. Knight Shyamalan's movies often have plots that chase their tails. This one is no different but James McAvoy's playing eight different characters is a treat.
Awful acting, deliberately awful dialogue, packed with action, pitch perfect setting for Vin Diesel to be Vin Diesel. Definitely guilty pleasure.
Writer/director Ben Younger blows a chance to make a powerful real-life Rocky movie. This one is an epic fail at almost every level. The worst boxing sequences of all time.
Gets a 1 just because I don't want the .5 to be mistaken for a 5. Even for what now passes as horror movies, awful on an epic scale. Bye Bye Man not worth saying hello to.
Washington has never been better. Davis is so good she could play a -- no pun intended -- fence post and get award nominations. A Christmas Day movie present worth the wait.
Fun for some but not for anyone not in tune with the humor of Seth Rogen, James Franco, Jonah Hill, Kevin Hart, Will Farrell and others of the new breed of movie comedians.
Book a ticket on this flight. The chemistry between the impossible not to like Jennifer Lawrence and Chris Pratt is good but it's the special effects that make this worth the ride.
For a movie based on a video game it's not bad. At least it's not bad for 2/3 of the film. The last act as expected, implodes.
The trailer promises a deep fantasy. Reality delivers a movie lacking beauty and with piles of collateral damage.
Deep, rich characters and a story to match. This one is golden from top to bottom and deserves the accolades it's getting. One of my favorites this year.
The 2:13 length and cookie cutter characters and events suck the life out of an underwhelming story. Great effects but the Force just isn't with this one.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Looks just like every other party movie you've ever seen. Four or five laughs in predictable places. Your own office Christmas party will be more fun.
Tom Ford's moody film features a dark, violent story set within another. Suffer from depression? Take an extra dose of whatever keeps you on an even keel. This is intense.
The rules that apply to actors disappearing for 15 years don't apply to Warren Beatty. Back with a bang in one of the year's best. One of this year's rare must-see movies.
Billy Bob's best ever character and the original was his best ever performance. Love the character enough to see it but it's not as good at being bad as Bad Santa.
Where Ben Affleck's acting skills falter, his directing and co-writing shines. This is a stylish piece of work. Worth seeing just for Elle Fanning's terrific performance.
If Ed Harris can't save a movie, it can't be saved.
Do we always have to do the last book in a series as a two part movie? Or three? Really? This one, however, is the best of the Divergent series movies.
Kudos to John Madden for doing a sequel that isn't worn out super heroes or so-so sci-fi. The movie works but is still the second best Exotic Marigold Hotel.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Joseph Gordon-Levitt's porn addiction topic may not be for everyone. However, it's a great first movie from a terrific young actor and now writer and director.
No need to rush right out and see this one. Barely made fresh in my book. Other than the last half-hour, this one has zip for tension, action or interest.
I ate this one up. Five writers and directors Cody Cameron and Kris Pearn, have produced one of the most clever, and funniest, animated sequels ever.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Getaway or One Direction: This is Us? I chose Getaway. Boy bands aren't my thing. A reel or two into Getaway and I'm thinking One Direction is a better direction.
All the ingredients of a good thriller are here, they just never come together and Closed Circuit doesn't deliver.
Cate Blanchett is going to clean up big time at the awards given out at the end of the year.
Nothing helps horror more than humor. People being hacked to pieces by a machete or having their throats cut just aren't topics that typically brings gales of laughter.
Funny but not end-of-the-world funny.
Lee Daniels' The Butler is deliberately and meticulously designed to grab Oscar and Golden Globe and other nominations for acting, writing and directing.
Kick-Ass did. Kick-Ass 2 doesn't.
Good take-off. Decent, sometimes even excellent effects. Bad landing.
The worst movie of the year so far. Period.
This is comedy not rocket science. It doesn't need to be realistic. We're the Millers is laugh out loud funny.
Decent Sci-fi. Neill Blomkamp gives the near future a negative, narrow, violent -- but probably more accurate than Star Trek -- view.
Like its summer cousin, The Kings of Summer, The Way Way Back connects the adult in all of us to the kid we once were. Or at least who some of us were at one time.
Why the Smurf do we need The Smurfs 2?
2 Guns is laugh-out-loud funny, armrest and jaw-clenching intense and -- simply put -- the best action movie done in a long time.
How about that? Someone conjured up a good ghost story!
R.I.P.D. is so bad that it should just drop the "D" and R.I.P.
The original Red was the most fun I had in a theater in 2010. Red 2 is likely to be the most fun I'll have in a theater in 2013.
A big chunk of the film's entertainment value is figuring out where writer/director Guillermo del Toro got his ideas.
I caught it almost a week ago, and I'm still laughing.
Most of us know the short and sweet Clayton Moore/Jay Silverheels TV version, but Gore Verbinski -- as he proved in Pirates of the Caribbean -- can't do anything quickly.
The action and characters are of the paint-by-numbers variety. Ignore that and it's guilty pleasure fun and way better than Olympus has Fallen.
Interesting. A film based on Greek mythology is done by a guy named Thor.
Big question. Is The Heat a good movie and really funny, or am I just in love with Melissa McCarthy?
The closet I've ever been to being in space. There are times when you want to ask Sandra and George to move over because they and the so-so story are blocking the view.
A good movie that gets a high rating but at 134 minutes, director Paul Greengrass' biopic engages in piracy of another kind: time piracy.
This Ben Stiller-directed and Stiller and Kristen Wiig star vehicle is not close to James Thurber's charming, classic short story but has a charm of its own.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Martin Scorsese directs so 1) the performances are incredible, 2) the movie is very long and 3) it is one of the year's best movies.
Kids crazy about dinosaurs -- find me one who isn't -- will love this one.
The best ensemble performance of the year and it's all true. Sort of.
Normally not a big Will Ferrell fan. This one, however, had me laughing. Out loud. A lot.
Great acting and a terrific plot save a storytelling flaw that has children not aging at all over a five-year period. I had trouble getting past that one.
The year's best movie. Period. And finally a best actor nod for Bruce Dern and add a nod for June Squibb who does the year's best supporting performance.
A better title: The Desolation of the Hobbit. It's more Lord of the Rings prequel. Extra stuff added that turns a good two-part adventure into a gazillion dollar making three.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Out of the Furnace jumps out of the furnace but missed the fire.
Familiar and worn holiday story saved by most excellent music.
Uncomfortable, powerful, brilliantly written and acted. One of the year's best.
No reason to run run to see Runner Runner.
Great in 3D and gratefully, the 3D isn't distracting. This is an animated feature to thaw the hardest heart.
Horrifying. Riveting. Must see.
Predictable. Yes. However, in spite of a zillion flaws, Delivery Man manages to deliver.
Didn't like the original. The sequel, however, does catch fire.
Robert's Redford has two-lines in the whole movie but his acting is still incredible. The movie isn't.
It's about time so it's a bit convoluted. It's too long but not a bad rom-com.
"Thor"t of good. Decent effects but not that ab-thor-bing.
Maybe the book is better.
No complaints about the acting or Ridley Scott's directing and cinematography. They are superb. Cormac McCarthy's writing is not so impressive.
Benedict Cumberbatch nails Julian Assange and looks and talks so much like the real thing that you often forget he isn't. It's a brilliant piece of work. The movie is not.
Barely fresh. Stallone. Schwarzenegger. In the same movie. Let the debate rage over who is the worst actor. And somewhere in all that bad acting is an equally bad plot.
Comparisons to the 1976 original are inevitable. Carrie is a first-rate horror movie. Period. And that goes for 1976 and 2013.
Dallas Buyers Club is one of the year's best movies and offers proof that Matthew McConaughey's recent acting accolades are not a fluke.
Sylvester Stallone is never better than when he's playing Rocky or a character like him. Add Robert Di Niro to the mix and presto: guilty pleasure.
Actors, it appears, do not have to grow up. And if this is your thing, then neither do you.
The dumbest premise in the history of Earth.
Chemistry is the reason things click. Actors with the ability to connect their characters to you always overcome a multitude of movie sins.
Automatic weapons? Bows that shoot bunches of arrows? Brain death for a plot? Witchery and demonic doings not even close to what the Brothers Grimm had in mind in 1812.
The story is what it is, and other than the ridiculous ending crisis, isn't bad. What drives the film is Marion Cotillard's acting.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Silver Linings Playbook is the best movie of 2012 and the acting is mind-boggling good. Give me the Oscar picks, and it wins in every nominated category.
Two-thirds of the way through Mama a psychiatrist hypnotizing a little girl asks her if she's asleep. Yes, she says. In fact, by then, so is the audience.
Fans of great 1960s rock and roll will love the incredible 40 song soundtrack but little else.
The acting and characters did it for me. The story? Promising. Not perfect.
The good news: Les Miserables is a less miserable film experience than expected. The bad news: it's still miserable.
Quentin Tarantino is seriously warped. But it's in a good way. His fertile imagination produces unique, albeit, violent and almost always, terrific movies.
A minor flaw or two but assuming you don't spend all of your days barefoot like a Hobbit, the movie will knock your socks off.
Soccer moms will find eye candy Gerard Butler good to look at if they can stay awake through his movie.
Director Steven Soderbergh and the cast get the mind working overtime with the prescription drug debate and then up the ante with a superb mystery.
Nothing soft about Killing Them Softly. Think early Quentin Tarantino in plot and dialogue structure and you get the picture. Gruesome. Yes. But oh, so well done.
The back story of the making and release of Red Dawn is more interesting than the movie.
Start with adjectives. Original. Stunning. Mesmerizing. Mind boggling. There are more, but you get the picture.
Too long, too many side stories but great work from Daniel Day-Lewis. Director Steven Spielberg often shoots him in poses that make him look like Lincoln's famous penny.
No rocket's red glare or bombs bursting in air for this Twilight's last gleaming.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Daring to broach the subject of how dated the characters and the series are, Daniel Craig, Judi Dench and director Sam Mendes make one of the best Bond's of all.
It's easy to focus on Denzel Washington's acting, but equally important to Flight is director Robert Zemeckis' storytelling and camera work. They give Flight its lift.
Wreck-It Ralph isn't great but it's not a total train wreck either.
The surfing scenes are spectacular. Unfortunately, those scenes cover about 30 minutes of a badly written, mostly boring 90-minute film.
Fun Size? No fun in any size.
Cloud Atlas brilliantly explores the cloudy topic of reincarnation.
Revenge becomes the dish served cold. In this case, non-entertaining cold.
This one is fun and is worth a couple of extra dollars for the 3D version.
The Man of Steel is not super, man. Not even close.
Suspension of reality is a must. But that's Die Hard, and this Die Hard die hard fans won't love but won't hate either.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Nicholas Sparks novel inspired movie is neither inspired nor novel. For those who love this stuff, your sugary treat awaits.
Not much magic here. Sometimes a great twist ending can make up a lot of lost plot ground, but even the end twist of Now You See Me is mundane.
Will Smith is a fun and funny guy. So why is Smith's sci-fi thriller screaming for a sense of humor?
Riveting. Michael Shannon nails this one. Rarely does a movie end leaving me wanting more.
A solid animated feature with a great message. It's good but not epic.
The hangover on the third day of a three-day binge makes you wonder why you decided to go there in the first place. Apparently it's the same for movies.
Five sequels may be a modern day record. In spite of a silly and unbelievable climax, this one is fun, and fast but not all that furious.
A good movie but unlike Abrams first effort, it doesn't boldly go where no one has gone before.
Gone is the rom-com character and emphasis on a toothy smile and six-pack abs. Matthew McConaughey is showing off some acting chops.
A great way to kick off the spring and summer blockbuster movie season!
The acting company Robert Redford keeps in The Company You Keep doesn't get any better. Movies rarely do either.
Somebody's real life murder should not be this much fun. But it is. And who knew the Rock would ever be this good an actor.
Beautiful Creatures is a potential cure for Twihards going through Bella and Edward withdrawal and ultimately it's also a good movie.
By the time director and co-writer Derek Cianfrance gets to the third act, it's a soap opera and not a very good one.
No home run but 42 does manage to go three for five at the plate. Harrison Ford's performance is the real reason to catch this one.
Traditionally, spring break flicks are teen angst induced romantic comedies. Brain death is the best description. Spring Breakers is a totally new way to do that brain death.
It's a remake so the chopping, slashing and mutilating isn't as much fun as Sam Raimi's 1981 original, but it looks more realistic. If this crap is your thing, enjoy.
There is nothing like experiencing this fabulous, larger-than-life, groundbreaking movie where it was meant to be experienced. And in 3D!
The 1950 Disney flick is 74-minutes. This one is 112. Does it need the extra 38-minutes? No. But it's a great story and a beautiful movie so the padding is forgivable.
Tina Fey and Paul Rudd are terrific. So is Lily Tomlin. The acting and chemistry works but this rom-com's story does not.
Olympus has fallen -- flat.
The most fun I've had in a theater all year.
The Incredible Burt Wonderstone just isn't.
I'm recommending only because of the fabulous effects in 3D. But in reality, it is neither great, nor powerful.
After Quartet, actor/director Dustin Hoffman should never direct again. Perfection like this cannot be repeated, and from here, everything is downhill.
Love the effects and Oblivion does have some interesting moments. For fans it will satisfy the sci-fi thirst for a short time until they start thinking about its many flaws.
Brilliantly done, inspired acting but the one-note plot has nowhere to go.
The Host just isn't a very good movie.
Flawed, multi-dimensional characters are a Coen brothers specialty. You'll like none of them but will love the movie and the music.
The book's critics say this the weakest of the three novels. True or not, the ultra slow Mockingjay - Part 1 is part one of a story that definitely doesn't warrant two parts.
Michael Keaton is a solid lock for the year's best male actor, his supporting cast is incredible and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's play-like film is a must-see.
Dumb. Yes. Dumber. No doubt. But To is too funny. At least in places. And enough of them to tickle my almost untickleable funny bone.
Christopher Nolan's movie about time has time troubles of its own. It's too long and drags to a convoluted climax. However, getting there is riveting and worth the trip.
Jake Gyllenhaal gives one of the year's best performances in a very well-done, intense thriller that looks at TV news from a bottom-feeding viewpoint.
The horror flick Saw started a chain-Saw of sequels and that is now one of the most successful of the chop-and-slash variety. It's not a bad way to spend a Halloween evening.
I normally love Jason Reitman flicks. This one feels unfinished and has a story that really has nowhere good to go.
A great cast is about all that helps a film based-on-a-true-story peek at a Reagan administration scandal.
I don't know much about Nicholas Sparks novels but do know movies based on them. They pretty much suck. What makes this one different is sucking at a higher level.
Complex but simple and full of life and the marionettes are wonderful. One of the best, if not the best, animated feature of the year.
Terrific acting and action sequences offset the slow spots and keep this from tanking.
Forget the boring other Madagascar movies with the lion and his friends. This one is hilarious. And it's a blast in ordinary two-dimensions or in glorious 3D.
Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad -- MOVIE.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like all horror movies, it starts with a really dumb premise. No one I know would buy a doll that ugly and put it in a newborn's bedroom. The movie goes downhill from there.
A worthy twisted and twisting whodunnit. Few novelists adopting their work to the screen understand the nuances of movie storytelling. Gillian Flynn does.
I know I should like it. It's produced by Laika. The stop-motion animation is imaginative and brilliant. But...
The camera loves Denzel Washington. He is always a pleasure to watch. Unfortunately, this movie is not.
Tom Hardy continues to stretch and James Gandolfini's last movie is deadly intense.
Jason Bateman and Tina Fey click and Jane Fonda has fun making fun of her breast implants but little else works and the rest is as dysfunctional as its topic.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A nail-chewing, intense and chilling thriller as riveting as Silence of the Lambs.
Seven Psychopaths is seven times the fun of most movies.
In real life Elvis had a stillborn twin. What if he'd lived? A fictional look at the possibility is more interesting as a sentence and a brief thought than a movie.
Brendan Gleeson is impossible not to like no matter what project. This one is a fascinating character study and a deep look at a complex man of the cloth.
November, December? June, July or even -- yes -- August. Pick a month, any month and this one is still bad.
Court is in session. Terrific acting and a patiently told story equal a most positive verdict. On my list of the year's best.
Inspiring in a bland sort of way and doesn't come close to standing as tall as the title.
For a sequel it is anything but horrible. Lots and lots of laughs and a most unique car chase at the climax.
Worst movie of the year. Six writers. Only four get credit. Moses and God aren't listed. But this is so bad it probably doesn't bother Moses and God anyway.
Great acting. Terrific movie. It's flaw is one faced by most directors doing a military biopic. Peter Berg fails to realize that less is more.
Neill Blomkamp rips off themes from better flicks like RoboCop and Short Circuit, adds language, violence and his unique style. If it's your thing, it's not bad.
The Lazarus Effect starts dead and cannot be raised from it.
Lots of hocus pocus but not much focus in Focus. Or, dare we say Focus is often out of focus? Either works. The movie does not.
Teen angst flicks are always formula. The DUFF is no exception. Once in awhile one is done right. This is a pretty good -- but very predictable -- flick.
The water in the tub is still lukewarm and it's pretty disgusting in places but tepid or not, I got a few laughs out of it and the outtakes at the end were funny!
Only one complaint. Why the heavy language? The R-rating keeps teens who'd also enjoy this really fun spy romp from enjoying the fun without mom and dad tagging along.
If soft core porn is your thing go for it but that's about all you'll get. Not a lot of grey matter used writing the script of Fifty Shades of Grey.
Though some parents and older non-parents are into Sponge Bob the concept is really aimed at little ones. A 90-minute film is painful for them - and us - to squirm through.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In spite of Andy and Lana Wachowski employing enough effects and CGI artists to populate a mid-sized city, Jupiter Ascending does more descending than ascending.
The acting is what drums up the interest here. J.K. Simmons proves -- as most of us already know -- he's a great actor and deserves more than acting for an insurance company.
The Theory of Everything is everything you didn't know about Stephen Hawking.
Ridiculous plot and unfortunately one you've seen a dozen times before and done better a dozen times ago.
Great movie but Eastwood misses digging really deep into the psychology of how a PTSD, shell-shocked veteran views a consumer, fun-based and somewhat shallow U.S. society.
What's with the fascination in 2014 about World War II? This is the best of three very good films and looks at the invention of the computer by an unusual cast of characters.
Great acting salts this complex mystery involving drug-addled bottom feeders in 1970s Los Angeles. It goes nowhere but typical of Paul Thomas Anderson, nowhere is riveting.
The paint-by-numbers portrayals of 1960s iconic players is pathetic and the story fails to capture the passion, energy and hope of MLK's leadership and of the times.
Wild is Cheryl Strayed's trip of self-discovery. It is getting an Oscar buzz for Reese Witherspoon. She's good but Laura Dern's work as Strayed's mom is much more deserving.
A bad remake of a bad 1974 movie.
A much darker and more interesting movie lies within the body of this one. While it's very good, and I really have no complaints, darker would have been better.
Widely but not surprisingly spurned for year-end awards, Angelina Jolie's film is long, often tedious but pretty good. I hear the book is better but what book isn't?
A fun and authentically original and trip into your favorite fairy tales. Acts 1 and 2 are terrific. The third act brings it down a bit.
The best of the now three - I even laughed twice -and it's the last time we'll see Robin Williams or Mickey Rooney. Swan songs for great actors deserve better.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The best of the three but the film's theme of the downside of greed is lost on Peter Jackson whose three films should have been one or -- at the most -- two.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: For the first time ever Kevin Hart mellowed out and didn't scream his lines like a chipmunk on amphetamines. It's an improvement but not enough. I laughed just once.
So slow, boring and badly written and acted that it's not If I Stay but how fast can I leave.
This is a delightful and original film for the first half and a sad imitation of a bad Scooby Doo episode the second. Delightful and original wins out and this is worth it.
Pure guilty pleasure. All Expendables are interchangeable but if you like movies one and two, you'll likely love this one.
Godzilla saves the world but can't save he? she? its? movie.
Seriously. No one would pay several thousand to sleep with a middle-aged guy who looks like John Turturro.
Dorothy's return doesn't give you much of a return for the time invested.
Would love to have Seth Rogen as a neighbor. He'd be a blast and probably more fun than his movies.
The not so amazing The Amazing Spider-Man 2 was enough fun when it was fun to recommend.
Couldn't make up its mind whether to do slapstick or more sophisticated brand of comedy and sadly, wasn't that good at either.
A barely bearable bear nature flick. Great cinematography. Boring story & script.
A technology run amok flick about artificial intelligence that isn't intelligent -- artificial or otherwise.
Kevin Costner is never better than when doing a sports movie. Draft Day wouldn't be my number-one movie pick but it's not bad if you're a sports movie fan.
Oculus is frighteningly good and light years better than most of the crap passed off as horror these days.
The governator's latest has more plot holes than the dozens of bullet-riddled bodies that inhabit this ridiculous story.
This is really aimed at an adult audience that grew up on the Muppets. By the 45-minute mark of the 112-minute movie, their kids or grandkids will be squirming in their seats.
I can recommend but the movie is hampered by a cookie-cutter societal threat and to mix metaphors, the paint-by-numbers plot turns painfully predictable at the climax.
This is all about speed and well-done dangerous dashes and spectacular crashes. They're fun. Unfortunately, at 130-minutes Need for Speed is everything but speedy.
Kids will love it. Adults -- especially those growing up on the original -- will enjoy the bazillion puns, marvelous wordplay and sense of humor.
This time you have the option of seeing all the blood, gore and bare chests and breasts in glorious 3-D.
Pompeii ends up an epic failure that doesn't show off the Mount Vesuvius disaster as much as it duplicates it.
Not a great movie but also not a bad way to spend an afternoon or evening.
It takes awhile to get into a groove but once it gets there Winter's Tale is one of this winter's best tales.
RoboCop -- even 27 years after the original -- is hard not to like.
Recommendable. Barely. It's like the first cut was too long so scenes connecting to pieces left in the final version were cut. What's left is a story with dots not connected.
For a movie with a derivative of give in the title this one has very little to give. If Jeff Bridges and Meryl Streep can't save a movie, it can't be saved.
Seriously good acting and Labor Day is a reasonable 111-minutes. However a draggy plot with nowhere fresh to go turns Labor Day into Belabor Day.
20-something relationship crisis rom-com's are a predictable A to B to C. How they negotiate the alphabet determines the outcome. This one has too many awkward moments.
After growing up in a dysfunctional family, movies about them sits at the bottom of my movie priority list. The acting, however, makes this a must-see.
It's always okay when a baseball movie goes into extra innings.
You'll love it if Marvel comic book movies are your thing. If not, it's a yawner.
Much of the adult humor zips over the heads of children, who will dig the characters and the action, and everyone loves the legos.
Intense, well-acted, worth seeing but the back and forth, past to present barely works.
Adjectives really don't do this one justice. Richard Linklater's 12-year project is brilliant. And bold. And innovative. And not to be missed.
Sandler & Barrymore. Great chemistry. They're terrific. Their movie is not.
Positive rating only because this was made for the now adult kids who loved this growing up and for their children and not for me. They aren't going to care that I hated it.
Entertaining in this or any galaxy. It's certainly the most fun I've had in a theater this year.
This is deep, wonderful stuff and is the year's best feel-good movie.
Where former A-list actors go to end their movie careers. Next stop, a really bad alphabet network TV series.
Great premise, terrific set-up, excellent effects and a world-class performance by Scarlett Johansson but ultimately it has nowhere to go.
A definite nominee for the worst kids movie of all-time.
Making a sex tape would be a lot more fun. Maybe someone also forgot to erase this movie?
Better than the original but better is a relative term.
A decent feel-good flick that features also decent music. The real reason to see it is the acting especially that of Mark Ruffalo who gives a career best performance.
Good movie, great effects but a bit slow in spots. What actually impressed me most is Andy Serkis -- who voices the ape leader Caesar -- getting top-billing.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A predictable twister plot needs some twists.
Love Melissa McCarthy. She can do no wrong. Her movie, on the other hand, does everything wrong.
Waaayyyy too long but not as bad as some are painting it to be. If this is your thing, what I, or other critics think, won't matter anyway.
Clint Eastwood gets a movie version of a gold record for this terrific retelling of the Broadway play of the story of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons.
22 Jump Street jumps off where 21 Jump Street ended. When it's funny, it's really funny. When it's not, it's REALLY not.
Just like the first film, when it's done you want to run out and pick up your own dragon.
Definitely the baddest fairy of them all.
Based on the "true" story of an African woman of British nobility and the role she might or might not have played in an historical anti-slavery legal decision.
How good this genre of film is depends on how the actors, writers and the director get from predictable A to Z. This one does it perfectly.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Jon Favreau has cooked up a great movie.
A better title, a million ways to laugh in the West.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In their scenes together, Foxx and Chestnut trade sly one-liners like front-line horn players in an intimate jazz club, while Union is given her best showcase yet for her comedic timing.
A coy, frantic attempt at screwball comedy, lightly seasoned and more than a little gummy.
Soupy, tedious mess.
Envy isn't a comedy so much as a welter of mugging, pratfalls and goofy attitudes struggling to coalesce into a comedy.
It's nowhere near innovative, but it scares you as you rarely get scared in movies these days.
Peralta shows himself to be something of a big-wave challenger here by breathing in bigger gulps of geography, history and culture.
A whodunit that keeps you guessing right to the end.
A resonant chamber piece for its talented actors.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What starts off as a spin on The Wizard of Oz turns into one of those Frank Capra-esque excursions into candy land populism with its windy homilies about 'nobodies' like Danny finding their inner 'somebodies.'
If you can stand the tumult, you may find yourself feeling giddy as you watch old pros like Nolte, Willis, Hershey and, especially, Finney play at such a high pitch.
Doesn't add up to much.
Michell and company try to make you forget that Enduring Love begins, literally and figuratively, on such a high level before tumbling into the sordid Hitchcockian precincts of dangerous obsession.
Fans accustomed to noisier, more graphic jolts may be impatient with The Grudge's measured insidiousness. Others may find it refreshing, curiously so.
Gandolfini and O'Hara are so gritty and wryly burned-out together that you want to express-mail them to another movie in time for next Christmas.
The movie can't find its center, but Linney nails hers. She alone makes this worth a night out of your life.
This version of Shall We Dance? tosses circumspection out of the window, milking every ounce of sentimentality, pathos and thrift-shop idiosyncrasy from the story line.
One could be forgiven for thinking of Raise Your Voice as a Disney Channel special that was mistakenly spun out into the multiplexes.
One could call it a romantic farce, except it's not much of a romance, not much of a farce and, despite the talent at work here, not much of anything.
[Hensleigh's] trying to pack in too much and the density clogs the narrative machinery.
Nestled comfortably in the lower-middle level of the they-won't- believe-me- but-the-truth- is-out-there subgenre.
A vehicle so neat, shiny and antiseptic that you could eat a three- course brunch off its surface.
You're more taken with its cleverness than swept up in wonder. Still, Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow's goofy, ephemeral pleasures are difficult to resist.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Toback's been known to get windy and heavy-handed with a setup like this. His films tend to get sticky from their overheated yearnings. Yet When Will I Be Loved has a surprisingly airy feel compared to his previous work.
Examines Rove's rise to power within the context of politics-as-usual. Such perspective adds power to the movie's punch.

One presumes [the original's cast] had better things to do than revisit old saw-toothed friends. Unless you have some empty hours to fill with swampy slush, you may decide you've better things to do as well.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What starts out as a crafty spin on the serial killer subgenre submits to overheated convention.
Fulfills its ambition to give these lost boys from Queens their considerable props, not least as inspiration for arty outcasts everywhere.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It programs its cheap laughs efficiently enough to make you think you're not really wasting your time.

If your pulse quickens when you hear lines like, 'Not so fast! I still have two cards face down, and they'll bring down your life points to a measly 1000!', then Yu-Gi-Oh is the movie you've been waiting for all summer.
Herky-jerky ripsnorter.
The usual bang, boom, crunch and screech, though maybe a little more stylishly executed than most.
The story's enchantment feels forced and coy, its mysteries tricked-up and flimsy.
An unkempt clearinghouse for cheap, throwaway laughs. For those who regard that as a recommendation, two words: Grow up.
Never convinces you that Alma's story is anything more than that of an amorous dilettante whose artistic bloom was delayed more by intellectual laziness.
By the seventh explosion, you can't help wondering whether all this flashy stuff amounts to more of a smokescreen shielding a lack of spine or soul.
Far from amounting to anything at all, except a fretless exercise in low-altitude farce.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

A starchy, overpowering helping of red, whiete and blue kitsch served up with piping-hot bombast.

Shamelessly manipulative.

Juicy, fruity, cunningly subversive.

Tells a lot more than it shows about its subject, looking more like an infomercial for Dick's legend than a true window into his art and influence.
movie_title: The Gospel According to Philip K. Dick (2001)

movie_title: Der Krieger und die Kaiserin (The Princess and the Warrior) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: As with other, similar movies, you do have to buy into brazen pulp operatics to get through it. Still, there's a rough-hewn energy to the movie's pre-digital flying-fist sequences that all but neutralizes the unapologetic hokum.
Weber's talent works best when he's focusing on an object, not when he's giving us a wayward, free-associating travelogue of his visceral imagination.
A tasty slice of droll whimsy.

A scenic, gentle diversion.
Riveting, if erratic.
So downscale it's liberating, so downbeat it's uplifting.

movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With its cast as counterweight, Birdman moves from a clever ouroboros to a passion project, rendered with confident artistic flourish.
Wild is a movie of living nature, with Witherspoon in the center, showing the most life of all.
Heartbreaking, unvarnished and thoughtful, Gloria is the story of a woman looking for the best that life can bring her. You'll be rooting for her to find it.

Unfortunately, with so many internal commitments to the franchise, this isn't a Captain America movie as much as a slice of Marvel pie in which Steve appears.
Though Simmons gnaws through the screen with every glance, Teller's a suitably brutal canvas.

A quiet but charming conversation with a man who's lived what he loves.

A rare vampire movie that feels both familiar and fresh, A Girl Walks Home is a wild, sometimes messy, always beautiful horror story, just the thing for a long winter's night.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It never rises above the ordinary.

movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The acting is richer than the story ... but this is a film designed to live or die on its twist. Good luck with that.

Turns an endearing collection of silly spooky stories into a busy, noisy, soulless eyesore.
A project that boasts all the appeal (and aroma) of a carcass rotting in the rainforest.

movie_review_blurb: The film seems inexplicably embarrassed by its roots, instead serving up half-baked and self-consciously contemporary drama that no one in the sure-to-be minimal theatrical audience will remember quite so fondly some 30 years on.

The type of sporadically silly and patently predictable horror pic that would look like filler on Syfy's weekend lineup, "The Other Side of the Door" brings virtually nothing new to the supernatural genre.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Silence is golden in "Hush," one of the more inspired concoctions to emerge from the busy Blumhouse horror-thriller assembly line in recent years.
If there are miracles everywhere we look, who wants to waste time on a movie this middling?
Hollywood's motivation for trying to cash in on a hot title is clear. It's not so easy to divine [David] Fincher's reasons for signing on.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: For anyone who wants to believe in the promise of Martin Luther King Jr.'s quote "the arc of the moral universe bends toward justice," a film like "Bending the Arc" is downright inspiring.

There's a fundamental miscalculation to the casting that drags down an already lumpy shaggy dog dramedy.

Woefully miscast as the seminal 17th-century French farceur Molière, the intense, black-maned young French movie star Romain Duris never seems more comfortable than the brief moments when he's rotting in a dank jail.
Klimt comes across as a lovely but unfathomable object, and an inadvertent case study in the argument for the ultimate integrity of Klimt's art.
Stardust [feels] episodic and clunky, constantly straining for the impression of overall coherent design that Gaiman renders invisible.
Skinwalkers announces its irony-impaired comic-shop geek credentials from the beginning.
Not quite as funny as a perforated ulcer.
While Ultimatum may be the lesser of the three Jason Bourne movies, it is only so because the bar set by its predecessors was so uncommonly high.
Resolutely predictable from the starting gate.

Some 10 years after expected, The Simpsons Movie couldn't give a doodle in a doughnut hole about expectations anyway. It may deliver what we've already got, but it leaves no doubt why we got it in the first place.
A shamelessly microwaved American rewarming of the 2002 German romantic comedy Mostly Martha.
While Manufacturing Dissent provides little that is new, it does place the controversy in the larger context of the contradictory relationship between the pursuit of fame and journalistic integrity.

The most impressive thing about Interview is how much shock it manages to muster over the walloping nonrevelation that, now more than ever, hype begets headlines. Next up: the rich are getting richer!
Both a salty comedy of uncompromising eccentricity and a requiem for a generation still sending sparks from fading embers.
Super '70s in both style and sensibility, Into the Wild does for vagabond New Age souls what Deliverance did for misguided suburban macho.
Everyone in this soggy tale of maternal reproductive instincts gone berserk is wisely attired in Wellingtons at one time or another, but it can't save them from sinking in the spreading sludge.

Never settling on a consistent tone or establishing a convincing context for its central character, the movie ultimately seems to grow bored even with itself.

The Kite Runner has become that most unfortunate of awards-season Hollywood casualties: a worthy bore.
More a collection of dubiously myth-serving, purple-hazed '60s' sketches than anything else.
Atonement is not only too polite but maddeningly orderly, resulting in a prettily cast, professionally performed, impeccably mounted bore.

With its rushed, jargon-pumped exposition, surplus of quarter-baked characters, stray narrative strands and generously dropped hints of things possibly to come, The Golden Compass is a movie that wears its franchise ambitions on its sleeve.

In this rippingly entertaining documentary of Reilly's celebrated autobiographical monologue Save It for the Stage, the unfailingly witty, shamelessly bitchy Reilly gets to set the record straight about a number of things.

If the real-life Christmas experience tends too often to be marred by the rude contradiction between expectations and reality, movies like the ultra-bland holiday family movie This Christmas are at least partly to blame.
There's no question Baumbach has a way with words and actors (Kidman, Leigh and Jack Black are terrific).
Exuberantly bad and strenuously preposterous.

Chuck and Larry remains something close to remarkable: an Adam Sandler movie that manages to be crude and caring in equal measure. In the multiplex, this is called progress.

movie_review_blurb: The movie functions crackingly well as a non-fiction international thriller.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In movie making, as in life, it's not enough to mean well. The real challenge is in being meaningful.

Ridley Scott's listless Big Statement is a wheezy, hot air-inflated dud.

At a time when family movies are usurped by fantasies of sentimental feelgood, Lumet's latest -- the mangled-heist melodrama Before the Devil Knows You're Dead -- delivers a swift kick straight to the jewels.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ratliff's movie almost succeeds in hurtling over the trenches it digs for itself in an increasingly ludicrous third act. But not quite.
How fitting for the film that a computer is calling the shots. But how disappointing for us that it can't punch up a script.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Directed with a conspicuous lack of inspiration.

movie_review_blurb: Venus adheres to the general parameters of conventional Hollywood with such cheek, intelligence and sheer self-deprecating nastiness that it does more to redeem the fantasy than it does the selfish and vain old geezer who is its beneficiary.

movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Freedom Writers confounds its own claims to veracity by coming across as a veritable textbook in itself -- a textbook of earnest, liberal, white-woman-in-the-blackboard jungle clichés.

movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

McQueen depicts the horrific experiences of Solomon Northup, the free man kidnapped and sold into slavery, in utterly unflinching fashion. The film's strength lies in its frankness and avoidance of either sentimentality or Quentin Tarantino-style irony.
The director Vincent Lannoo doesn't have quite the Lubitsch touch but, in its own slightly flimsy way, Paper Souls makes pleasant enough viewing.

What gives the film such a kick, in spite of its improbabilities, is its raw and brutal but also very subtle portrayal of the shifting, attritional relations between teacher and student, sorcerer and apprentice.

A film about someone going on a very long walk doesn't sound especially dramatic but Nick Hornby's screenplay (adapted from Strayed's book) brings out Cheryl's yearning as well as the epic quality of her mini-Odyssey.
A film that grows more powerful the darker it becomes.

Mortdecai is reminiscent of some of the wildly misfiring comedies that Peter Sellers used to make in the 1960s and 1970s - the worst of the Pink Panther films, or the star-studded fiascoes such as the 1967 Casino Royale.
This is a misconceived and strangely cast affair that can't work out its own attitude toward its main character.
Charlie Lyne's documentary about modern teen movies is entertaining and insightful, but also scattergun in its approach.
