[Documentary maker Nicolas Philibert's] admiration for Radio France's work and public-service ethos is self-evident, but this is a very hard film for a non-French audience to engage with.
The director Mariana Rondón elicits a moving and unaffected performance from Lange as the boy desperate to please his mother even as he realises how much his behaviour vexes her.
Trash is an honourable addition to the list of films about Brazilian street kids that stretches back to Héctor Babenco's Pixote and Walter Salles's Central Station.
Watching Paul Thomas Anderson's wonderfully textured and intricate LA-set Inherent Vice, you are easily reminded of the famous story about Howard Hawks' version of The Big Sleep.
From here, the film begins its rapid slide into absurdity, invoking every action movie cliché imaginable.
The film deals in a subtle and moving way with grief and teenage anxiety while serving up all the thrills of a big-budget animated movie with superhero protagonists.
[Jupiter Ascending] blends astonishing special effects work with plotting that would barely pass muster in a bad Saturday morning episode of Flash Gordon or Mighty Morphin Power Rangers.
What makes Mann such a fascinating but paradoxical film-maker is his grandiose approach toward material that often seems utterly formulaic.
[It's] offbeat and entertaining enough to stand a fair chance of achieving cult status in future years.

Smith is again playing a hustler and shows his familiar charm and charisma. The film itself plays like an ersatz version of one of David Mamet's dramas in which everybody is cheating everybody else, but it suffers from a lack of plausibility.
It has a delicacy and a hand-crafted feel that you won't find in the latest DreamWorks or Pixar blockbuster. Instead of brash primary colours, Takahata uses a pale and watery palette.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film combines wit with mind-boggling inanity but is so brash and good-natured that it is very hard to dislike.
The plotting is wayward and haphazard but the film is made and performed with such frankness and emotional intensity that its occasional stumbles never seem a problem.

The Oscar-winning director Susanne Bier and her trusted screenwriter Anders Thomas Jensen have made some fine movies in the past but this one, with its absurd plot about stolen babies, plays like an overwrought Victorian potboiler.
The director Etan Cohen neither gets the best out of his two leads nor manages to give his story much of a satirical or political kick.
Wild Tales is a raucously entertaining collection of "six deadly stories of revenge". The brilliance of the film (produced by Pedro Almodóvar) lies in its combination of excess and ordinariness.
Intermittently, SpongeBob's latest feature is very funny indeed, even for non-devotees of the original series.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It least Insurgent has very lively performances from Woodley as the action heroine, James as her square-jawed beau, Ansel Elgort as her detached brother Caleb and Miles Teller (from Whiplash) as the Iago-like Peter.
Oscar-winners Jeff Bridges and Julianne Moore deliver two of the hammiest performances of their distinguished careers in Sergei Bodrov's overcooked sword-and-sorcery fantasy.
Frédéric Tcheng's fascinating documentary looks at the attempts by the Belgian fashion designer Raf Simons to revitalise Christian Dior with his first haute-couture collection.
The Face of an Angel is a fascinating but perplexing film, which typifies its director's offbeat approach to whatever subject matter he tackles.
Opulently shot and designed, full of spectacular, tourist brochure-style imagery of Brazilian buildings and landscapes, the film teeters on the edge of novelettish melodrama throughout.
Spectacular action, chases, races and fight scenes are combined with plotting and dialogue of mind-numbing crudity and plenty of shameless product placement in the latest sequel.
The appearances of Robin Williams and Mickey Rooney (who have both since died) adds extra poignance to a film that pretty much follows the contours of its predecessors.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A remake of a Dutch movie that itself wasn't much of a success.
This isn't an exhaustive or especially insightful documentary about Robert Altman (who died in 2006) but it successfully reminds us of what made him such a special director.
Chris Weitz's screenplay updates the old Charles Perrault yarn in a fresh and witty way. The performances are very lively too.

Slumdog Millionaire is an exhilarating ride -- a feel-good yarn about a Mumbai street kid directed by Danny Boyle with a wild energy that makes even Trainspotting (Boyle's calling card) look leaden-footed.
The film is gory, odd (with its scenes of talking animals and severed heads in fridges), horribly uneven but intermittently very funny in its own tasteless, grand-guignol fashion.
It has a kick that most other Hardy adaptations have conspicuously lacked.
This perfectly amiable comedy sequel can never quite transcend its own Saga holiday brochure-style complacency.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Rob Cohen's half-baked erotic thriller plays like a misguided homage to Eighties video fare and to family-in-peril sagas like Unlawful Entry or Cape Fear.
The ingenious new teen horror film It Follows will intrigue, puzzle and trouble audiences by turns.
Director Kornél Mundruczó's staging of the scenes in which the dogs take to the streets is breathtaking.
Loraine directs at a very brisk pace but you can't help but feel he could have made his points more effectively in a documentary.

There are some clever and provocative ideas about artificial intelligence swirling around in Chappie, the latest feature from the District 9 director Neill Blomkamp, but much of the film is derivative and messy.

Vince Vaughn would make an excellent Willy Loman in a revival of Death of a Salesman. Here, he has the presence, charm, desperation and sense of yearning that characterise Arthur Miller's doomed anti-hero. Unfortunately, this is a very goofy comedy.
Too portentous to work as an action-hero romp, and far too sweaty and derivative to have any kind of political or satirical kick, the movie misses almost every target at which it aims.
An exemplary piece of verité film-making.
Araki blends film noir-like elements with an engagingly offbeat, Adrian Mole-like look at adolescence.
[Renner gives] is a rousing performance but the film is a little one-dimensional in its portrayal of Webb as a result.
What lifts the film is Johnson's visual style and Ferdinando's utterly committed and intense performance as the corrupt cop.
The writer-director-star Desiree Akhavan's lesbian romcom is well observed and often very witty.
Suite Française is handsomely made and boasts two exceptional central performances but its tone is strangely discordant.
The latest Liam Neeson vehicle is an enjoyably overcooked latter-day film noir with a heavyweight cast all mugging it up.
This heartwarming, very British drama plays like a soft- centred teen version of a Mike Leigh movie.
Writer-directors Glatzer and Westmoreland have written a rich, multi-layered screenplay that works equally well as family melodrama and as a meditation on language, identity and mortality.
This is a complex and very moving documentary.
It combines abstruse ideas about gravity, matter and time with old fashioned, hyper-charged family melodrama.

Frederick Wiseman's fascinating and uplifting documentary takes us into the heart of London's National Gallery, showing us everything from the painstaking work of frame-makers to heated boardroom meetings and even dance performances.
Collins has a gamine-like quality reminiscent of a young Audrey Hepburn but her effervescent charm isn't enough to hide the chronic absurdities in the storyline.
Before its inevitable final-reel decline into cutesy mawkishness, this family comedy (produced by Shawn Levy) has an enjoyably subversive and anarchic edge.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In its lesser moments, the film feels like a European art-house adaptation of a Mills and Boon novel or a Saga holiday commercial, but it is beautifully shot and packed with cameos from big-name actors.

Nightcrawler deliberately blurs the lines between David Cronenberg-like satire, crime thriller and horror. It also poses as a twisted version of the traditional story about the all-American entrepreneur, trying to get ahead any way he can.
Moss has put the documentary together in painstaking fashion, somehow managing to be there, filming discreetly, at all the most intimate and climactic moments.
On the level of a fairground ride, the film delivers but when it comes to such matters as emotion, character development and suspense, it's a bust.
This is a weird and self-indulgent affair that is easy to mock but that, just occasionally, captures the romantic feel of the equally pretentious but magical Leos Carax films of the late 1980s.
Alexandre Aja's sprawling, wildly uneven film suffers from its continual shifts in storytelling style. It's at its best as a Twin Peaks-style mystery with supernatural elements.

There is the risk of a credibility gap when charismatic and successful stars play ultra- dysfunctional types. That's why Bill Hader and Kristen Wiig never quite convince as Milo and Maggie, twins on the cusp of middle age.
The wonder of Andrey Zvyagintsev's brilliant new film is that it works both as a Chekhov-style family tragedy and as an extremely barbed satire exposing corruption in contemporary Russia.
This is an intelligent and probing drama but one that lacks the oomph factor you might expect in a real Oscar contender.

Lawrence is again tremendous as Katniss. She gives her character an emotional depth that you don't expect in a franchise movie, conveying her vulnerability and doubt as well as well as her fiery determination and Barbarella-like sex appeal.
The performances are as rich and moody as the cinematography.
There have been many recent films based around memory loss, but few that most adults will want to forget as quickly as Nativity 3.
In its lesser moments, the film seems as banal and manipulative as any afternoon TV soap. Another way of looking at the film is as Haggis's own very idiosyncratic and intimate essay.
The Australian writer-director Jennifer Kent's bravura new horror pic combines subtlety and psychological depth with some very full-blooded shock tactics.
Gorgeous visuals, lively voice work and makes inventive use of Mexican history and culture - in particular, The Day of the Dead. Its actual storytelling is a little flat.
This is a dark and primal story about love, jealousy and greed. Its problem is that the Oscar-winning director Susanne Bier doesn't know what to do with her two incongruously glamorous stars.
Fury is a thoroughly contradictory affair. It is an anti-war film that also wants to be an action thriller.

This is a rousing Gothic bloodcurdler with all the trimmings: impalings, sword fights, swarms of bats, punctured necks, remote Transylvanian landscapes, non-stop spectacle and occasionally very ropy CGI.

Russell Crowe's directorial debut is a solid, old-fashioned piece of film-making set in Australia and Turkey during the First World War and its aftermath that is guilty of some strange historical oversights.
[Hencken] makes a very persuasive case for Spandau Ballet's place in the Britpop pantheon.
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The set-pieces are effectively handled, with a few goose-bump moments along the way, but the story makes no sense whatsoever.
Heery has an excellent cast, and he elicits some very funny performances... However, the slapstick and gags risk getting in the way of a story about love, loss and broken families.
Yann Demange's brilliant debut feature is an honourable companion piece to Carol Reed's 1947 classic, Odd Man Out.
A fascinating, albeit strangely downbeat, costume drama.
The film itself, for all the richness of its content, is a strange and unsatisfactory hybrid -- a cross between a conventional documentary and a guided tour of a gallery.
Twenty years after Four Weddings and a Funeral, Hugh Grant is still playing a variation on the dithering, charming Englishman. This is one of his better recent vehicles.
Much of the dialogue for this terminally mawkish tearjerker sounds as if it has been taken directly from a Dolly Parton or Whitney Houston song.

The film feels like a TV sketch stretched to feature length and some of the gags are crass in the extreme but it is intermittently funny and perceptive on top-level modern footballers and celebrity culture.
The director Gia Coppola (granddaughter of Francis Ford Coppola) gets under the skin of protagonists who seem like pampered, listless delinquents on the surface but who all turn out to be lost souls.
Those poor old Teenage Ninja Turtles should have been left tin hibernation.
The film-makers Peter Strickland and Nick Fenton manage to bring a sense of mystery and wonder to what was clearly more than just another gig.
For all its contrivances and occasional lapses into On Golden Pond-style mawkishness, this is a richly crafted yarn that boasts barnstorming, if very showy performances from Duvall and Downey Jr.

This recently restored 1920s British war film is a revelation -- a silent movie that, for all its jingoism, is shot and edited on a scale and with an ingenuity that invokes memories of the great Soviet silent movies.
movie_title: The Battles Of Coronel And Falkland Islands (1928)

movie_review_blurb: The fascination of the documentary lies in the fact that Poitras was there with her camera at the crucial moments, when Snowden was sharing the information that would cause such convulsions all over the world.

A film about a movie critic might not sound an attractive proposition, but Steve James's biographical documentary on Pulitzer Prize-winning, Chicago Sun-Times journalist Roger Ebert (who died last year) is deeply moving.

Structurally, the film is a little cumbersome. The footage of Gandhi, Nelson Mandela and other heroes of peaceful protest is a distraction. The three main stories, though, are inspiring and shocking by turns.

If Paddington is to turn into a movie franchise, one suspects that marmalde sandwiches under hats and scenes of mayhem in kitchens and bathrooms won't be quite enough. Far more attention will need to be paid to the storytelling.
Director Mo Ali has an obvious flair for action -- but little instinct for story or characterisation.
One of Kenner's main points is that the debate itself is being held on false grounds.
Into the Woods is a strangely patchy and episodic affair. Some of it is dazzling; some of it would barely pass muster in a provincial Christmas pantomime.
As for the gloopy sentimentality, that has always been an essential part of Annie's DNA. You couldn't make a film about her without it.
It is beautifully shot and has the same fierce intelligence about it that you find in its producer's other epic "quest" movies.
The occasional uproarious moment is small reward for the long scenes we're forced to endure of Carrey and Daniels gurning and grinning as if they are fresh out of bedlam.

Joseph L Mankiewicz's adaptation of the Frank Loesser Broadway musical, itself adapted from Damon Runyon stories, looks a treat. The wonder of the film is that it combines widescreen colour and opulence with an earthy, street-level humour.
Depending on your perspective, Nadav Schirman's troubling documentary is either a story about heroism and friendship or a study in extreme treachery and bad faith.
It turns out to be a rousing, full blooded war movie but one which also sometimes feels derivative and a little heavy handed.
Director Tom Harper makes inventive use of the settings.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Chilean actor Paulina García deservedly won a Best Actress award at this year's Berlin Festival for her exuberant, warm-hearted performance as Gloria, a divorcee in late middle age who still has an extraordinary lust for life.

In Fear is a slickly made, impressively pared-down horror/thriller but is too abstract for its own good - it is hard to feel any great emotional identification (or fear) for characters who so sketchily written.
Marsh has somehow made a tearjerker (albeit a highbrow one) about the life and times of a Cambridge physicist - and that itself is an achievement.
The plotting doesn't make much sense but Cage gives a typically flamboyant and uneven performance as the stubborn old agent.
Foxcatcher is brilliantly acted and extremely well crafted in a wintry, slow burning way but has an emptiness at its core.
What is laughable here is the extraordinarily clunky way in which the screenplay (co-written by the film's producer Luc Besson) combines family melodrama with random chases and fights.
Big Eyes is Tim Burton's most intimate and subtle film since Ed Wood, to which it feels a companion piece.
This documentary tells a fascinating story in a very heavy-handed way.

The latest in Disney's Tinker Bell computer-animated movies is a sprightly affair, made in eye-popping iridescent colours, full of stardust and with enough narrative verve to keep the mawkishness at bay.
movie_title: TinkerBell and the Legend of the NeverBeast (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The actors, though, lift the material. The most poignant performance comes from the late Robin Williams in a cameo as Nikki's neighbour and friend.

Not since John Wayne and Montgomery Clift set off on their epic cattle drive in Howard Hawks's Red River has there been a more unusual pairing than Tommy Lee Jones and Hilary Swank in Jones's magnificent new feature, The Homesman.
Winter Sleep demands patience, but if you last the course, you will soon understand why it so enraptured the Cannes jury.
The film does repeat itself and seems a little stretched at feature length -- but there is plenty of hilarity along the way.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As we learn more about the tormented family backgrounds, broken love affairs and suicide attempts of the protagonists, the film begins to sag under the weight of its characters' mounting self-pity.
It is dismaying to see the brilliant Idris Elba and Sam Miller, his director from TV's Luther, working on low-grade exploitation fare like this.
The film tapers off in its final reel, ending on a conventional note -- but not before it has done its best to capture its subject in all his manic and absurd glory.
"We need to find an exit right now," someone shouts early on. Audiences may well find themselves sharing the sentiment.
It is very impressively shot by cinematographer Si Bell. Deyn, meanwhile, brings intensity and pathos to her role as the hyper-sensitive but always resilient heroine.
A movie comprised almost entirely of battles could have become very tedious indeed. Jackson, though, is always able to give an intimacy to even the biggest, noisiest scenes.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The writer-director Ted Melfi's comedy provides a perfect platform for Bill Murray.

Christopher Smith, better known for horror films such as Triangle and Severance than yuletide mush, does a fair job of adding some grit to the typical Christmas film. It helps that he has Jim Broadbent playing Santa Claus with such avuncular glee.
Parts of Men, Women & Children are very acutely observed and have real poignance. The problem is the Short Cuts-style structure, with its multiple characters and overlapping storylines.

Penguins of Madagascar is an unexpected pleasure, a 3D kids' animated feature that combines a wildly inventive visual style with enough in-jokes and self-reflexive references to keep film- loving adults happy, too.
The Grandmaster is an anomaly -- a mournful and delicate kung-fu movie with hardly a trace of machismo about it.
The director Kevin Macdonald does a very good job in capturing the claustrophobia and fear that a submarine crew feel as a mission goes wrong.

The computer animation of the characters is expressive and detailed (we even notice the freckles on the shoulder of the heroine) while the film-makers work wonders with glacial landscapes in a land of "eternal winter."
The film itself turns out to be a traditional, linear account of the Moses story that could have been taken from one of David Kossoff's bible stories.
This is a likeable and smartly written teen movie that still seems very fresh in spite of rehashing characters and situations familiar from countless other high-school comedies.
This exercise in Eighties computer-game nostalgia is strangely misconceived.
This remains an astonishing achievement: a Dystopian sci-fi epic that is also one of the best film noirs of recent times.
What makes one child persecute another? Do bullies really change as they grow older? It is while exploring these questions that the film is at its most intriguing.
Its contradictions are obvious but its one consistent quality is it humour. Amy sees the comedy in everything from divorce to death and, most absurd of all, her own romantic longings.
Lightweight but stylish and enjoyable in a high-kitsch fashion.
This gritty, very intense Spanish thriller has the feel of an Iberian True Detective.
It is a comedy with barbs and an unlikely undercurrent of pathos.
The filmmakers take great pleasure in highlighting the cultural differences between the British and the French in every area from gastronomy to lovemaking.
The film is thankfully shorn of the sentimentality which weighed down The Fault in Our Stars.
This drama is an intensely patriotic affair, which plays at times like a canine version of Clint Eastwood's American Sniper.
Tiller Russell's fast-moving, invigorating documentary will make very gratifying viewing for fans of all those New York-set cop movies by Martin Scorsese and Sidney Lumet.
The filmmakers use slick editing and pounding music in a desperate bid to paper over the cracks in their own storyline.
Makhmalbaf's highly original new film is a tragicomic drama about the toppling of a dictator. The twist here is that the drama is seen from the perspective of the dictator himself.
As in Kevin Macdonald's recent submarine drama Black Sea, the film has moments of intensity and tension but risks becoming a trial of endurance for audiences.
Zac Efron is a long way from his High School Musical roots in this surprisingly dark and self-conscious drama about a young DJ from the San Fernando Valley.
Straight Outta Compton is an unwieldy, expletive-strewn sprawl of a musical biopic.

Some of the set-pieces -- chases through airports, fights on train tracks, car crashes or helicopters hurtling into skyscrapers -- are very niftily choreographed but you can't help thinking this would be more fun as an interactive game.
[A] bubbly but very lightweight high-school comedy.
At its best, the film is very funny. At its worst, it makes you groan in dismay.
Me And Earl And The Dying Girl is funny, highly original and very moving too, even if it becomes a little gloopy in its final reel.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There is a soulfulness to Pacino's performance, but this is a downbeat and dispiriting drama about broken families.
Teller, Mara and company are very capable young actors who bring sensitivity and humour to their roles, but that isn't necessarily what audiences want from Marvel-era superhero blockbusters.
Love & Mercy, Bill Pohlad's ingenious biopic of Beach Boy Brian Wilson, approaches its subject from a very unusual direction... ear-first.
Moore is dealing with dark subject matter in playful and, at times, quite magical way.
Manipulative and unabashedly sentimental, The Choir carries loud echoes of other better movies.
It is typical of Orson Welles that he takes a B-movie thriller set on the Mexican border and gives it a Shakespearian grandeur.
It is the universality of the film that makes it an instant classic. Inside Out combines simplicity with extraordinary formal daring and sophistication.
Tarsem Singh's sleekly shot sci-fi thriller begins intriguingly but loses its identity.
It is never clear whether the film is a study in journalistic bad faith, a courtroom procedural or a drama of very different characters who provide a twisted reflection of one another.
In an era of smooth and sanitised teen movies, it is refreshing to encounter a film as idiosyncratic, dirty-minded and self-consciously wayward as this.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film boasts handsome production values and is as intricately put together as the device Elser so painstakingly assembles.
There are some beautiful shots of desert landscapes, plenty of scene-stealing work from the camels, and, early on, some very picturesque shots of the British countryside.

The episodic storytelling style can seem haphazard but the writer-director Alice Rohrwacher succeeds wonderfully well in capturing the richness of the kids' lives in their own remote and often brutal world.
Wenders showcases his work while giving him a platform to express his philosophical and political views. The doc benefits from a subtly affecting use of music.
Johnson is a modern-day renaissance man who'll be quoting William Blake one moment and belting out some R&B with Roger Daltrey the next.
The best that can be said is that director Anne Fletcher keeps the tempo very brisk, leaving as little time as possible for us to work out why we are not laughing.
Dizga Vertov's 1929 experimental Soviet propaganda picture is breathtaking in its formal ingenuity.
Its plot line doesn't bear too much scrutiny and its characterisation is sketchy but the action itself is frequently exhilarating.
Boxing movies tend to be exercises in masochism, machismo and redemptive melodrama. Southpaw hits all these targets square in the midriff.

It is refreshing to encounter an action-adventure with a Lilliputian lightness of touch. The downside, though, is that Ant-Man seems very insubstantial fare by comparison with Iron Man, Captain America et al.
Johnny Depp gives an utterly chilling performance as the notorious James "Whitey" Bulger in Boston-set crime drama Black Mass.
Liv Ullmann's adaptation of August Strindberg's play might best be billed as a midsummer night's sex tragedy. It is on the overwrought side.

This is a weepie so wildly manipulative that it is bound to provoke an allergic reaction in many viewers. If it doesn't bring you out in hives, you may still admire the fearlessness with which the film-makers and their cast wade so deep into the treacle.
There is a moral somewhere in Captive but it is hard to work out what it is.
Hopkins is in a scene-stealing groove but Solace turns out to be an overcooked affair, fussily directed and far-fetched.
Niki Caro uses every device at her disposal to make a rousing, feelgood movie but risks turning the film into a glorified fairytale in the process.
Wonderfully vivid.
Life is a listless biopic that doesn't even try to capture the neurotic intensity of James Dean as a young actor.
We are so used to sci-fi movies in which the heroes shoot martians with ray guns that Scott's botanical approach can't help but seem offbeat and refreshing.

The screenplay (by Bahrani and fellow film-maker Amir Naderi) subverts the tropes of the typical self-help story. It portrays a society in which the only opportunities for success are provided by the failures of others.
The director Robert Zemeckis is one of the true visionary figures of recent American cinema.

Co-scripted by the Coen brothers and British writer Matt Charman, it is a consummately crafted, richly layered affair, with fine performances from Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance. The one hitch is that it is just too wholesome.
This is a very ponderous affair, pitched in some purgatorial wasteland between cop thriller and Rosemary's Baby-style Satanic drama.
Sicario may leave an unpleasant taste but it is a slick, accomplished thriller.
The problem here is that the film-makers throw too many elements into the mix. Grand Guignol bloodletting is combined with characters and ideas which often seem to have been borrowed from Rebecca.
It's a powerful tale of lost innocence, albeit sometimes heavy-handed in its depiction of the plight of African child soldiers.
Wright stages some very colourful set-pieces, but the film-making never takes wing. It doesn't help that the performances are as broad as any you will find in a pantomime at the Hackney Empire.

Razvan Radulescu's screenplay is rich in irony and reversals, highlighting tensions between generations, and between the wealthy elite and the people whose lives are blighted by the elite's unthinking behaviour and desperation to cling to its status.
It is effective in its own dour way and some of the set-pieces are magnificent but, watching it, you feel as if you are being pummelled.

This is a grating, sometimes very violent comedy-thriller that suffers from a chronic identity crisis. The film can't work out whether it's a slacker romance or an all-action spy movie in the Manchurian Candidate mode.
Its narrative missteps notwithstanding, this is a movie on the grandest scale, one that really does induce a sense of awe.
Jack Black gives one of his most nuanced and affecting performances in this oddball indie comedy.
The thriller No Escape has one or two moments of brilliance interspersed with many very silly ones.

Without Streep at its centre, this might have seemed a flimsy confection. But she plays the rock singer with the utter conviction and fearlessness that she brings to all her roles, however unlikely they seem.
What is refreshing about Dope is its cheerful irreverence.
Matthew Heineman's documentary about the Mexican drug wars plays like a real-life version of some grim Sam Peckinpah Western in which violence and corruption have become endemic.
Hardy gives an utterly fascinating performances in his dual role.
This is a transgender story that is very careful not to startle or offend its audience. That is one reason it doesn't have quite the emotional kick that might have been expected.

Shyamalan creates a creepy atmosphere and some of his shock tactics are effective. The Visit, though, is the kind of movie you expect from a first-timer searching for a voice, not someone with his experience.
Richard Bracewell's Elizabethan-era comedy, starring the cast of Horrible Histories and Yonderland, is brisk, cheery fare that yields as many laughs as it does groans.
The latest Maze Runner isn't a patch on its near cousins, The Hunger Games and Insurgent.
This cheery French comedy-drama is sustained by its own rude energy.
Irrational Man is one of Woody Allen's most disconcerting films of recent times -- a very dark story told in a breezy and playful way.
It's both a "true crime" movie and a poetic account of two young men who, by committing an act of unspeakable brutality, unleash the furies against themselves.
Horse Money is hermetic to the point of being baffling, but in its dream-like way it is atmospheric and intriguing.
This clunky, claustrophobic, Aussie-made dystopian thriller has a plot that seems to have been constructed out of odds and ends from Ridley Scott and Christopher Nolan sci-fi movies.
A Walk in the Woods is unabashedly sentimental and sometimes as slow-moving as its two curmudgeonly leads but it has an undeniable and redemptive charm.
Shot over five years, it became a heartbreaking portrait of a marriage unravelling.
The film isn't so much a conventional narrative as an elegy and a parable.
One of the pleasures of an intermittently very funny film is its sly and subtle approach toward the attrition between generations.
Terminator Genisys suffers from a fussed-over, convoluted and self-referential screenplay that manages the feat of being both incredibly complicated and strangely simple-minded.
There's a lot of star wattage in Peter Bogdanovich's new screwball comedy but none of it shines very brightly.
A German-made kids' movie, Two by Two is cheery, innocuous fare, sentimental but with some spirited chases and slapstick sequences.
movie_title: All Creatures Big and Small (Ooops! Noah is Gone...) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Match's slightly wooden trajectory is compensated for by Patrick Stewart's compelling performance as the brash, outwardly confident but fundamentally lonely Tobi.
There are some inventive moments along the way, but these are interspersed with lots of posturing, yelling and brawling.
Hal's eventual betrayal of Falstaff ("I know thee not old man") is the most poignant moment in all of Welles' movies.
Brand puts across a familiar message in a very lucid and entertaining fashion.
Beautifully shot and absurd.
Céline Sciamma's girl-gang movie is a disarming affair, a long way removed from the macho posturing of other French films set in the Banlieue, such as La Haine.
The film is at its strongest in the scenes between Bathsheba and Gabriel Oak (Matthias Schoenaerts).
The big-screen spin-off from TV's Spooks is an old-fashioned affair -- a ripping yarn with more than a hint of John Buchan about it.
After the arrest, the storytelling becomes more grim but Stewart never loses his sense of satire.
Its tongue-in-cheek humour and lapidary one-liners are combined with some well-staged stunts.
The film's trump card is its rigorous honesty.
The film, set in north London, is stylishly shot and Gillen plays the troubled lead with a mercurial mix of swagger, self-loathing and self-pity.
Argerich gives a far more intimate, offbeat and complex portrait of an artist than could ever have been provided by any non family member.
This is the post-apocalyptic movie to end all post-apocalyptic movies. There is even more dust, rust and decay here than in the original films. The credits themselves are in molten red lettering.
Pitch Perfect 2 is a very fragmented affair, more a selection of comic sketches than a coherent movie in its own right.
Christian Petzold's Phoenix is a darkly melodramatic tale told in a very unmelodramatic fashion.
This is a poignant and entertaining affair, with enough of a satirical edge not just to seem like an exercise in cosy British nostalgia.
The plotting is predictable but the film has heart and charm all the same.
One of the strengths of the film is its accurate and barbed portrayal of changing British social attitudes.
Ryan Gosling's directorial debut is a misfiring, wildly self-indulgent affair, but with flickerings of brilliance along the way. Individual sequences play like short films in their own right.
Mirren's performance gains in depth and pathos as the film progresses.
This is the kind of movie that will make you want to go back in time -- to the moment before you made the rash decision to start watching it.
Its saving grace is the sheer operatic excess of the bloodletting.
Ruben Ostlund's subtle and probing drama lays bare the tensions and misunderstandings in a seemingly happy marriage over the course of a week's skiing holiday.

Hawke is quieter and more dour than he was playing the husbands and fathers in Linklater's films. However, he is very effective at capturing his character's pent-up frustration, self-disgust and mounting aggression.
The film emphasises Cobain's creativity as well as the work ethic that went alongside his well-chronicled drug use.
This Victorian-set horror film can't help but seem a missed opportunity. It has the ingredients for a lurid and entertaining trip to the dark side.
In such a bleak and distorted world, it is perverse to try to tell a whodunit story with conventional heroes and villains -- and yet that is what this misguided and contradictory film attempts.
Dark Horse plays like a documentary version of an Ealing comedy.
Slow-moving and sometimes very bleak but benefits from two exceptional central performances.
This is an exercise in nostalgia as much as bloodletting. The filmmakers are paying their very own tribute to teen-horror pics of the 1970s.
It's the detail -- the fly on the dead man's face and all those close-ups of characters' stirruped boots clanking on wooden floors -- that makes The Salvation so enjoyable.
Whedon brings a depth and wit to his storytelling that you will never find in a Transformers movie. Even so, the final showdown is a little anti-climactic.

For all its more far-fetched moments (King Charles XII of Sweden dropping in on a contemporary Swedish café on his way to and from battle, say), the film is perceptive in its depiction of human behaviour.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film is predictable but affecting and often funny in its depiction of the young Sudanese attempting to adjust to US culture.

Kendrick puts across her songs with toothsome charm and conviction but the flashback structure is cumbersome, the music isn't distinctive and Jamie is such a preening narcissist that you can't help but think Cathy is well rid of him.
An undercharged as well as under-dressed affair that can't ever quite overcome its own cumbersome screenplay.

There has already been one very good documentary about the maverick American director Sam Fuller... This new film, made by his daughter, Samantha Fuller, covers similar terrain but in a much more personal way.
This is the quintessential Hawks movie, combining spectacular aerial sequences with the fatalistic barroom machismo of the pilots off duty.
Even seen in 3-D on the very biggest IMAX screen imaginable, Jurassic World is a glorified B-movie at heart, one that has its tongue firmly in its cheek.
Joshua Oppenheimer's The Look of Silence is a gruelling film to watch and one that ought to answer the criticisms leveled at his previous feature doc, The Act of Killing.

This is a deeply personal film which also stands as an intriguing record of a period not often revisited in film -- that drab period postwar and pre-Suez in which the country itself, like the flailing young hero Rohan, is struggling to define itself.

Christian Schwochow's late 1970s-set drama about young East German woman Nelly (Jördis Triebel) trying to build a new life in the west has some of the same mix of pathos and paranoia that characterised The Lives of Others.

Gazza, the Geordie football genius who lived on a proverbial diet of brown ale and Mars bars, is just as you would expect: engaging, mischievous, funny but also haunted and sometimes just a little bit prey to self-pity.
In its own shameless, unreconstructed way, the film version is sometimes very funny. It is also crude and relentlessly chauvinistic.
Against all odds, [Monroe] gives an extraordinary performance.
What it does offer are some wildly colourful, jaw-dropping anecdotes from their friends and collaborators about their working methods.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: By focusing on these winegrowers, Nossiter is able to make familiar but still relevant points about globalisation and the potentially disastrous consequences of industrial farming techniques.
For this kind of comedy to work, absolute precision and relentless speed are essential. Given the circumstances in which the was made, it is little surprise that neither are achieved.
Gibney is too subtle and diligent a film-maker to indulge in a one-sided hatchet-job. The tone of Going Clear is inquisitive, not sensationalist.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Lynch shows some visual flair with a few clever, Tarantino-like touches but the film overall is a deadening and claustrophobic experience, in which the human interest diminishes as rapidly as the body count rises.
This very wry, LA-set adult comedy plays like a junior, low-budget version of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
Sugar makes you fat. That, predictably, is what the young Australian film-maker Damon Gameau discovers for himself from his own expanding midriff in this engaging, Super Size Me-style doc.
As the title suggests, Maclean is in no hurry. Even at the most climactic moments, he always looks for an offbeat perspective.
The Minions are sometimes very funny. They have a winning way of gargling out dialogue. The problem is a plot that is as indeterminate as their body shapes.
Director Pablo Fendrik makes evocative and dramatic use of his jungle settings.
The film is colourful and humorous in its evocation of Swinging London and celebration of Lambert's idiosyncrasies.
Given the ingenuity with which the director Leigh Whannell orchestrates the stunts, it is a pity the plotting is so creaky.
The stag humour is crude and boorish and even the slapstick is very clumsily executed.
Tomorrowland is weakened by its own relentless optimism.
Alongside the shock tactics, Kenan's Poltergeist also works well as a study of a squeezed middle-class American family struggling to survive in a punishing economic climate.
The film is so stylishly shot, and performed with such swagger, that it transcends its own pretentiousness.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This yarn, based on Tove Jansson's Moomins comic strip, is a wistful and gentle affair, hand-drawn and far less brash than the typical animated Hollywood feature.
Demoustier and Duris give real heart to characters whose behaviour could easily have seemed absurd.
Amir Amirani's documentary will jog memories about the sheer scale of the anti-war protests in Britain in February 2003.
The film has the feel of a glorified TV movie and lurches into Misery-style melodrama in its final reel.
The problem is that spy movies have been spoofed so many times that the jokes often feel as tatty and old as the CIA's rodent-infested headquarters.
An impressive piece of work, a lesbian melodrama which is probing, thoughtful and finally very moving.
As a helter skelter, fairground ride, San Andreas is often exhilarating but the fault lines in its screenplay become more and more apparent.
The writer-director Guy Myhill brings an engaging mix of abrasiveness and lyricism to a film that seems at times like a British equivalent to David Gordon Green's early films.
It has some of the same comic absurdism that ran through Chris Morris's Four Lions, but the satire is combined with lyricism and a sense of mounting tragedy.
The ritualised action sequences work well enough. It's just a pity the film-makers did not pay as much attention to the plotting as to the design of the movie.

Danny is a role tailor-made for Pacino at this stage in his career, one that enables him both to indulge in some very hammy scene-stealing, but also to show his character's vulnerability and essential decency.
It's the level of detail that most impresses, the painstaking attention the filmmakers have paid to recreating 1970s France and to explaining just how far Zampa's criminal network extended.
It is Bell's film -- she is sassy, cynical, funny, occasionally self-pitying and gets most of the best lines.
There is an unutterable sadness at the heart of Asif Kapadia's brilliant new film about Amy Winehouse.
Some intriguing ideas lurk within writer-director Mike Cahill's screenplay, but he would have to be a Stanley Kubrick or a Jonathan Glazer to do justice to them.
It is a sweet-natured and melancholy film, beautifully directed, that manages to be satirical about love in a digital, distracted age without losing its heartfelt quality.

One of its wonders is that, in spite of its grim underlying themes, Ida has the lightness, grace, humour and visual inventiveness of the New Wave movies of the Sixties to which it pays such obvious homage.
Fiennes and his team recreate 19th-century England with a precision that, in its more stifling moments, rekindles memories of Merchant Ivory.
Claire Denis' wonderfully murky, Paris-set film noir turns usual thriller conventions on their head. She pays far more attention to character than narrative or action.

For all its tremendous production values, George Clooney's The Monuments Men is a profoundly frustrating and unsatisfying film. Clooney simply can't settle on a tone for the story he is trying to tell.
Adults who go to The Lego Movie out of a weary sense of parental duty are in for a very pleasant surprise.
[A] formulaic romantic comedy.
The plotting itself is clumsy and predictable, and the sub-Office-style jokes are often flat-footed. Frost himself, though, is an engaging screen presence.

Alain Guiraudie's thriller is characterised both by its formal ingenuity and its surprisingly graphic gay sex. The plotting rekindles memories both of Patricia Highsmith novels and of Hitchcock films.
Brilliant but frustrating by turns.
Unfortunately, the film's magical- realist approach comes off as kitsch and preposterous.

Hiddleston and Swinton excel as the very refined bloodsuckers, conveying a sense of world-weariness and disillusionment about the behaviour of the "zombie" humans without ever becoming remotely wearisome themselves.
Werner Herzog's venture to Transylvania seems as much inspired by German romantic art (Caspar David Friedrich, especially) as by Bram Stoker or Bela Lugosi.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Bondarchuk doesn't skimp on the widescreen spectacle. At its best, Stalingrad has a visual dynamism and full-blooded quality reminiscent of the best work of Sergio Leone.
The battle scenes are spectacular but lifeless and hard to engage with. We're watching a cascade of computer-game imagery.
Mahdi Fifel's poignant documentary about everyday life in Ain el-Hilweh, a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon, offers a very different insight to that given in news reports.
The film's attempts to expose flaws in the criminal justice system or give insights into the war against terror seem superficial, but Closed Circuit is entertaining in a sub-Hitchcock way.
What makes the film so special is its sense of defiance and its scabrous humour.
Not so much a feature film as a series of cinematic doodles and self-reflexive ruminations on the subject of obsessive love.

Louis Malle's supremely stylish New Wave thriller combines Miles Davis's music, Henri Decae's wonderfully evocative black-and-white cinematography of Paris and plenty of close-ups of a young Jeanne Moreau looking very anguished.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: DreamWorks' latest animated feature is an engagingly witty, if bizarre affair about a hyper-intelligent dog, Mr Peabody, and the young boy, Sherman, he adopts.
If audiences stop trying to unravel the very tangled plot and don't mind have the carpet pulled from under their feet again and again, they should find plenty here to relish.
Downey is a brilliant actor who somehow manages to portray Tony Stark as traumatised without losing the character's laidback and comedic quality.

It is heartening to find a teen-oriented movie franchise as gritty as The Hunger Games. Even so, Catching Fire remains contradictory, caught in some nether world between nightmarish political allegory and adolescent escapism.
The disappointing aspect to Captain Phillips is that it doesn't go beyond action movie conventions.
Lucy Walker's documentary is exhilarating and grim viewing.
Camalier makes an excellent job of combining talking-head interviews with music, anecdotes and folklore.
This charming feature doc offers an anatomy of a marriage.
[Director Alan Taylor] is helped by Tom Hiddleston's sleekly malevolent performance as Thor's untrustworthy brother Loki, a more engaging and complex figure than Chris Hemsworth's monosyllabic Thor.
Regardless of its initial box-office performance, The Selfish Giant will have a very long shelf life and will be watched for years to come.
Much of the humour here is barbed and cynical.
Larraín shows how idealism and venality sat side by side, how quickly the brutal circumstances in which Pinochet came to power were forgotten and how little seemed to change once he left.
It is very derivative -- but it has been made with diabolical amounts of energy.
Panh's remarkable new documentary works as a survivor's testament, a film about memory and loss -- and as a self-reflexive essay asking how atrocities should be depicted on screen.
A Field in England defies easy categorisation - and that is its glory. Ben Wheatley's English Civil War drama/horror picture is a wondrously strange affair that bends genre rules.
The Brazilian director José Padilha may be working for a Hollywood studio but he doesn't temper his critique of American imperialism, big business and political corruption.
The Lobster is a European arthouse film par excellence - precisely the kind of project you can't imagine ever being made in Hollywood.
Warm Bodies is an ingenious hybrid that, at its best, manages to be funny, lyrical and gruesome.
The director seems uncertain whether he is making a slow-burning character drama or a satirical gangster movie about modern-day Seoul's answer to the Borgias.
Some of the film is gruesome in the extreme but there is always lyricism and pathos alongside the bloodletting.

What is startling here is the eye-popping colour, the self-reflexive photography and visual effects, the dance sequences (Fred Astaire with his umbrella), and the witty and ingenious use of the Paris locations.
Unconvincing in the extreme.
This is a slickly made, energetic teen sci-fi yarn, let down by its derivative and schematic storyline.
For all its beauty -- and in spite of Glass's majestic music -- the effect is bewildering.
The rambling plot may resemble a lyric from a mawkish country song but the film-makers bring an engaging mix of tenderness and grit to the downbeat material.
There is enough colour, wit and inventiveness here to make this acceptable enough Easter holiday fare for children and adults alike.
The film lacks a real sense of menace or conviction.
It is a stylised and idiosyncratic affair, combining deadpan humour with a real sense of existential terror.
Absurdist dramas staged with grace and ingenuity, these "dangerous acts" draw attention in eloquent and very affecting fashion to the plight of Lukashenko's victims.
movie_title: Dangerous Acts Starring The Unstable Elements Of Belarus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Mark Cousins' essay on children and cinema is playful and profound.
movie_title: A Story Of Children And Film (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ejiofor's role might not be as gruelling as his turn in 12 Years a Slave but he gives a nuanced and powerful performance as another character whose certainties about his life are undermined by brute circumstance.
This is a real charmer of a film: a wry and gently comic Mumbai-set drama with a level of quiet observation that rekindles memories of Bill Forsyth in his prime.
This sci-fi drama begins promisingly but loses its way in the Martian dust.
This murky Scandinavian conspiracy thriller about deep-sea divers during the Norwegian oil boom of the 1980s suffers from a plot so convoluted that it makes The Big Sleep look straightforward.
An enjoyably half-baked foray into the paranormal.
There's a delicacy and lyricism, a handcrafted quality here not found in contemporary, CGI-animated features.
It is adolescent male wish- fulfillment fantasy of the most retrograde kind but, as action cinema, the Jakarta-set thriller The Raid 2 is riveting fare.
Biblical epics don't come any more soggy or bombastic than Darren Aronofsky's Noah.
It's the detail and precision of his storytelling style that makes All Is Lost so engrossing.
[Soloway] delves fearlessly into raw, intimate and uncomfortable areas that more conventional comedies would avoid like the plague.
There is plenty of brash, Mel Brooks-style humour here but the plotting becomes increasingly soporific and repetitive.
The film-making style seems disconcertingly glossy given the downbeat themes.
Don Argott's documentary about the heavy-metal band Lamb of God would have been a conventional rock doc if it had not been for a tragic incident at one of the band's concerts in Prague in 2010.
movie_title: Lamb Of God's As The Palaces Burn (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As buddy movies go, this is strictly formulaic fare but it elicits a few laughs along the way thanks to the relentless goofing of Kevin Hart.
The film is remarkably faithful to Eastwood's version. It carries on a long tradition of exchange between Westerns and Japanese samurai films that stretches back to Kurosawa and Sergio Leone.
Singer captures intimate moments in the lives of his subterranean protagonists in their strange, crepuscular world.
Aldo Fabrizi excels as the courageous priest and there are few films that have a finale as heartbreaking.
Brilliantly directed by Kotcheff, the film has the disorienting and menacing quality of Joseph Losey films such as Accident and The Servant.
Low-budget horror films based around found footage began to seem outdated not long after The Blair Witch Project but this British excursion into the form is surprisingly enjoyable.
Low-budget action thrillers don't come with any less velocity than Bullet.
The characterisation and plotting are as crude as the car chases are slick.
The problem is that the protagonists are so unengaging.
The trajectory of the film is predictable and the ending is horribly maudlin, but Butler makes his points about masculinity, trust and friendship in droll enough fashion.
At least, the director's imagination remains as freeflowing and fervent as ever.
This documentary prises out French (but Algerian-born) businessman Jean-Yves Ollivier into the light and reveals the remarkable role he played in the end of apartheid.

From Scarlett Johansson's wonderfully sultry femme fatale Black Widow to Robert Redford's self-satisfied politician and Samuel L Jackson's tough and sardonic Nick Fury, the film benefits from performances that combine camp with conviction.
20 Feet from Stardom, this year's Oscar-winner for Best Documentary, is both rousing, upbeat fare... and a film steeped in a strange sense of yearning and regret.
The film works both as advocacy and as a very moving study of women (and one or two men) whose idealism and patriotism have been utterly shattered.
Helping anchor affairs, though, is the bear-like Gandolfini, who brings charm and gravitas to a movie that might otherwise have seemed very superficial.
Brie Larson is very impressive as the caring, funny supervisor whose own demons threaten to engulf her.
The film-making has a lyrical quality more in keeping with Terrence Malick's Tree of Life movies than Harlequin romances.
The dialogue is tin-eared in the extreme, the 3D is used in a strictly tokenistic fashion and the absolute lack of a sense of irony or humour makes the more solemn scenes all the more laughable.
Imagine Martin Scorsese in Ambridge adapting The Archers and you'll come close to its essence.
Bravura moviemaking: a wildly ambitious psychodrama about a ballerina consumed with angst and jealousy as she prepares for her biggest role.
The strength and importance of Miral lies in its vantage point. Schnabel is offering viewers a perspective on the Middle East that they are unlikely to have seen before in other mainstream movies.
In patches, it is entertaining and ingenious. However, the director seems fatally uncertain whether he is making a full-blown action movie or a spoof.
This film gives us more access than the most inquisitive tabloid magazines into Phoenix's world. By doing so, it makes us question and even become a little ashamed about our own voyeurism.
Quote not available.
It is part of the richness of 3.10 to Yuma that this is a classical piece of storytelling with themes and characters that can be found in the very earliest Westerns.
Coppola's film-making style is detached and low-key.
Duncan Ward's muddled satire about the London art world has a strong cast mugging for all their worth.
The Fighter proves that the boxing movie still has life. It also underlines just what a distinctive actor Bale has become.

What would otherwise have been a sleazy exploitation picture is lifted by Tamahori's flair for filming action and by an exceptional performance from the British actor Dominic Cooper in the dual role of Uday and his double.
Quote not available.
Ralph Fiennes's Coriolanus is a bloody, testosterone-filled updating of Shakespeare's play, shot and performed with real vigour. This is the Bard done action-movie style.
Woody Allen's latest film is a pleasant, if very undercharged affair, which unashamedly basks in every last cliché about Paris as a city of artists, intellectuals, gourmands and lovers.

You have to admire Terrence Malick's cussedness and perversity. No other major American filmmaker, not even Stanley Kubrick at his most wilful, has ever made a film quite as idiosyncratic as The Tree Of Life.
It's to Affleck's credit that he strives so hard to put a personal imprint on such generic material.
It's a well-observed and often funny account of how, in 2007, Sarkozy landed the presidency.
Coppola may be working on, for him, a smallish budget (reportedly around $15 million) but that doesn't mean his usual craftsmanship has abated. The film is sleekly shot and edited.
Nowhere Boy has just about enough music and biographical detail to appeal to Lennon and Beatles fans but it's far more intimate than the typical rock star biopic.
A sprawling, brilliantly acted character study which touches on love, friendship and betrayal, while also managing to recreate the last days of disco without a note of self-parody.
Bay fails to bring any insight to his treatment of the event.
Cabiria's story is indeed heartrending, but neither director nor actress allow her time for self-pity.
movie_title: Nights of Cabiria (Le Notti di Cabiria) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Adolescence was never supposed to be this wholesome.
The humour may be vicious, but there's also a strong vein of pathos running through the film.
The old energy and bite may be lacking, but at least this lazy, amiable shaggy-dog story was made in the same freewheeling, idiosyncratic way as Altman's best work.
A handsomely shot but stolid drama.
A wildly inventive film straitjacketed in conventional narrative form.
Brutal scenes are undercut with lyricism and deadpan wit.
A fascinating, consummately crafted and ultimately moving study of a man who conforms surprisingly closely to western archetypes of the artist as rebel and hedonist.
The real rot is in the script.
If Chris Paine's film were half as well designed as General Motors' super-sleek, super-quick EV1 (the electric car whose demise it laments), it would be a film to cherish.
Some cases are harrowing, but the film is never grim. The formidable Ngassa shows such resilience, kindness and common sense that the effect is oddly uplifting.
Quantum Of Solace doesn't seem like a major entry in the Bond canon. Well under two hours long, it's shorter and more frenetic than most of its predecessors, and an often-jolting experience to watch.
Oliver Stone has a terrible sense of timing. This is a film that has been overtaken by events and already seems out of date.
What the film lacks, for all its inventiveness, is the sense of menace and sadism that bristles through Dahl's best stories.
Self-consciously elegiac, The Yards is a slow-burning but meticulously crafted family melodrama posing as a thriller.

There is a strong whiff of Beckett-like absurdism and bleak humour in the film, which benefits from a performance of wonderfully droll dignity and bemusement from Brendan Gleeson as a priest confronting his mortality.
For all his recent travails, Gibson remains a formidable film-maker (Apocalypto was a tour de force) and a strong screen presence. He is simply not right for his role here.
Quote not available.
The actors (all likely to be in awards contention) are clearly enjoying themselves.
Anderson aficionados are bound to warm to Moonrise Kingdom. Non-fans may take more persuading, but should enjoy themselves in the end.
The Angels' Share is Loach at his most playful and invigorating.
In its own miasmatic way, the film is arresting and original.
Serious flaws notwithstanding, this is a formidable film. Audiard's least thriller-like work to date, it's an essay in harsh realism.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Fearlessly acted by Margarete Tiesel, Love makes its often cruel points about colonialism and exploitation quickly and effectively, then bangs them home at repetitive length.
A hyperbolic tone, some dire over-acting and much verbose political debate made this a leaden trudge, resembling a rendezvous between Ken Loach and Barbara Cartland on the banks of the Nile.
Both a surefire crowdpleaser and a magnificent piece of film-making.
This is Shannon's movie and underlines his status as arguably the most exciting US screen actor since Pacino and De Niro were in their heyday.
If not a full blown triumph, this is certainly one of the best Bonds in recent memory.
Thankfully, Jackson's flair for action sequences and bold and complex production design hasn't deserted him.
Quote not available.
Taken as a ghoulish fairground ride, James Wan's Grand Guignol shocker eventually delivers the jolts and thrills it promises.
A visual triumph even if its storytelling is less than sure-footed.
Frears manages to get the tone just right. Even the most jaded of audiences will find it hard not to be moved by Philomena's quest for her missing son.
McAvoy played Macbeth on stage not long after acting in Filth -- and you get the sense that Robertson was the perfect preparation for stepping on to Shakespeare's blasted heath.
Phoenix's performance is as fragmentary and uneven as the film itself but has an energy about it that reminds us of why he seemed such a distinctive screen presence before his untimely death.
Ozon ... attacks his material with huge zest, playing up kitsch elements but never losing sight of more serious points.
Quote not available.
The formal ingenuity is often breathtaking. This, though, is not a movie that tugs at the emotions in any way.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Due vite per caso (One Life, Maybe Two) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
The invention here is often still dazzling, the race sequences are invigorating and spirited voice work atones for the inexpressiveness of the cars themselves. Even so, this isn't Pixar at top gear.
McGregor, in one of his most assured performances, helps anchor a film that could have seemed very fey and far-fetched indeed. He underplays beautifully.
Quote not available.
The sub-Porky's style humour elicits a few guffaws, but a little more wit and subtlety would have helped.

Extremely well-crafted and acted, the film was warmly enough received at yesterday's screening. But it lacks that sense of political idealism and indignation that made Clooney's earlier directorial effort, Good Night, and Good Luck so stirring.
Lurie makes the same point as Peckinpah, namely that, when survival is threatened, even the most civilised types have a primal capacity for violence. But, 40 years on, the shock factor has gone.
The film plays like a hi-tech version of cheesy 1950s sci-fi fare of the Quatermass or Invasion Of The Body Snatchers variety.
Whatever else, Tinker Tailor underlines the strength of British character acting.
This is the filmic equivalent of a relay race. Some legs work very well but, during others, Meirelles and his team risk dropping the baton altogether.
Quote not available.
Fresher than ever.
The largely British cast strive gamely to salvage a film that takes itself far too seriously.
A chilling, cautionary tale.
There are some magnificent elements here... The downside is the mawkishness and the rambling narrative structure.
For all its formal restraint, the film is just as subversive and as disquieting as predecessors such as Crash and The Naked Lunch.
For all its attractive elements, The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is hoary, unconvincing fare. The cobwebs are beginning to show.
What makes it so special is its mix of barbed humour, tenderness and its Adrian Mole-like insights into what teenage years are really like.
There are some guffaws and the actors look as if they're enjoying the Riviera locations, but dignity is in short supply.
The storytelling doesn't match the visual effects.
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film is as tangled and ingenious as any of Welles's conjuring tricks. The shoot-out in the hall of mirrors is the most famous sequence, but there are other moments just as memorable.
The Purge films are the kind of lean, clever exploitation pics that you could imagine Roger Corman making in an earlier era.
Guardians Of The Galaxy is Marvel-lite: a brisk and breezy superhero movie that provides plenty of visual spectacle and humour but is sometimes undermined by its own facetiousness.
The film-makers create a genuinely unsettling atmosphere and crank up the tension in effective fashion... Unfortunately, in the final reel, the film lurches into Grand Guignol silliness.
High kitsch it may be but Mood Indigo is certainly a welcome antidote to the usual terminal illness melodrama.
Nonetheless, at its best, it has some of the same qualities as Ophüls' [Letter from an Unknown Woman].
This cutesy E.T.-like sci-fi drama is utterly undermined by its own shooting style.
In what is a very uneven film, the director Trish Sie delivers exhilarating musical set-pieces alongside often crass and clumsy characterisation.
The tone is very different from that of Boys from Brazil-style thrillers. This is a stately art-house drama, well shot in wintry landscapes, which plays like a coming-of-age story.
Its cast features some of Hollywood's most redoubtable character actors, among them Philip Seymour Hoffman in one of his final appearances before his untimely death earlier this year.
The writer/director Hong Khaou's chamber piece boasts some wonderful performances from veteran Chinese actress Pei Pei Cheng, Ben Whishaw and the still dapper Peter Bowles.
This Disney cartoon is running on empty.
The comedy works by a process of attrition. When one gag fails, another follows it until, eventually, the film hits the funny bone.
Stallone is the square-jawed hero. Gibson is the square-jawed villain -- and that's about as much story as we get.
The ever-likable Simon Pegg holds together this whimsical but affecting comedy-drama about a London-based psychiatrist pondering the metaphysical meaninglessness of existence.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Hide Your Smiling Faces is a beautifully shot, highly stylised portrait of American adolescence.
As the documentary makes clear, those accusing him of misdeeds don't exactly have clean hands themselves.

The trajectory of the film is as predictable as that of Georgie's best free kicks, but director David Scheinmann recreates the Eighties in exemplary fashion and tells the boy's story with heart and humour.
One secret Rattner refuses to divulge is whether this is a full-on spoof or whether he is actually making the film in deadly earnest.

As invigorating and funny now as it was on its original release half a century ago, A Hard Day's Night offers both a perfect showcase for the Beatles and an intriguing snapshot of fast-changing, early-1960s British society.
Felix Herngren's adaptation of Jonas Jonasson's best- selling novel is undermined by a fatal lack of charm.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Linklater] has fashioned a drama that feels far more authentic than any other coming of age movie.
Keira Knightley plays Greta, a Norah Jones-like singer-songwriter... It's a typically brave performance from an actress who is always prepared to try anything.
Much of the writing is witty and erudite, and as flamboyant as the visuals. It's just a pity that the film droops markedly as it goes on.
The film is a little too soft-centred to do justice to its own themes of bereavement, jealousy and family breakdown.
The filmmakers borrow freely from Avatar, Sword In The Stone and even Brave but they bring enough vigour and imagination to their storytelling to get away with it.
Green specialises in a soulful naturalism, and Joe contrasts moments of Malick-style lyricism with scenes of extreme brutality.
An extraordinarily intimate and moving portrait.
The interviewees and even his mother, with whom he was reconciled late in his life, all portray him as a generous and very sweet-natured man.
Finding Vivian Maier is a tantalising and utterly fascinating film but one which can't ever quite explain the mystery of Maier.
Diaz is dealing with primal emotions in a contemplative, visually striking way.
[A] cheery but half-baked canine caper.
What could have been a very gooey, toe-curling exercise in self-congratulation is lifted by Shep Gordon himself.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Given the constraints under which he must have been working, being filmed with motion capture technology and under layers of heavy make-up, Serkis' performance is extraordinarily expressive.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The plotting may be contrived but Zlotowski cranks up the tension effectively enough as Rahim has to deal with both the threat of radiation poisoning and the consequences of his illicit affair.
This is a strangely listless affair, which seems as bereft of energy as its meandering twenty-something protagonists.
This is a French comedy with claws.
In its lesser moments, the film is overwrought and derivative but, at its best, it has a real flavour of Friedkin, Coppola and Scorsese.
The occasional awkwardness of God Help the Girl is part of its considerable charm.

The film-makers highlight just how formulaic most romcoms are in their attitudes toward everything from race (they're invariably about white couples) to class and such stock types as angry ex-husbands.
Seventy-five years on, it hasn't dated in the slightest.

There's plenty of Tim Burton-like wit and humour behind the Boxtrolls concept. The film boasts some lively voice work, too. Its problem is a script that is as flat as cardboard. It takes quite a while to work out what is happening or why.
There is no real sense of urgency here. Anton Corbijn's chilly, detached directorial style doesn't help.
Hans Petter Moland's icy, Norwegian-set thriller treads an uncomfortable line between hardboiled Nordic noir and tongue-in-cheek humour.
This is a real-life sporting fairy-tale that suggests success can still sometimes be achieved in British football without the largesse of absentee foreign owners.
movie_title: Jack to a King - The Swansea Story (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film portrays grimy, late-1990s Brooklyn in atmospheric fashion, throwing in shots of run-down tenements, graffiti-strewn walls, disused parking lots and sprawling cemeteries. The plotting is less assured.
This may be a retrograde adolescent wish-fulfilment fantasy, sadistic and violent, but it's also slickly made and has real satirical bite.
Robert B Weide of Curb Your Enthusiasm fame co-wrote the screenplay but, sadly, none of the debunking wit of that series is found in this solemn, sappy fable.
Forsyth and Pollard's approach is reverential rather than critical but the film is beautifully shot and its impressionistic approach is a welcome antidote to that of most rock docs.
Anthony Baxter's follow-up to his 2011 documentary You've Been Trumped is an impassioned and often very funny affair.
Magic in the Moonlight feels like the work of a 78-year-old director. If you're prepared to indulge him, though, it is also a film of considerable, playful charm.
This is a shocking and moving account of how the Bernstein documentary was shot, edited and shelved.
This is an eccentric, Quixotic but highly enjoyable affair.
An effective thriller in a similar mould to Washington's films with the late Tony Scott.
Somehow, Fincher imposes coherence and clarity on a complex and messy storyline.

The Danish director Lone Scherfig does a fair job of conveying the brutishness of her protagonists, their sense of entitlement and their vicious snobbery. Laura Wade's script (based on her own play Posh) is very sharply written.
Among the great strengths of The Dark Knight is the way it combines hardboiled naturalism with the kind of stunts and setpieces you expect in summer blockbusters.

The Hundred-Foot Journey is a culinary culture-clash comedy enlivened by fiery performances from Helen Mirren and Om Puri but which, like so many other Lasse Hallström films, slowly turns to gloop the longer it lasts.
Sex Tape is wittier and less smutty than its reputation might suggest.
It would be overstating it to suggest that Besson is enjoying a major creative renaissance but Lucy is the best film he has made in a very long time.
Its plotting is predictable but Kazan and Radcliffe make a thoroughly engaging double act.
The Dardennes' latest feature has an epic quality that belies its small-town setting.
Unfortunately, long before the storm has blown itself out, the plot has long since come apart.

The director Scott Derrickson seems uncertain as to whether he is making an exploitation pic intended to give audiences a few fairground-style thrills and frights, or a William Friedkin-style meditation on the nature of evil.
This is a chilling study of domestic abuse.
movie_title: Die Frau des Polizisten (The Policeman's Wife) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The film might not be Tarantino's masterpiece but it is his most entertaining and exhilarating effort since Pulp Fiction.
This is a droll and well-observed comedy thriller that recreates the 1970s in convincing fashion while retaining enough of a sense of menace to avoid ever drifting off into whimsy.

Reichardt probes away at her characters' motivations and contradictory feelings. She doesn't judge them, but makes it very clear how quickly their idealism becomes muddied once they dirty their hands with direct action.
Writer-director Robespierre's low-budget comedy-drama is both caustic and heartfelt.
The yuckiness here comes from a manipulative and sugary screenplay that makes even the terminally lachrymose The Fault in Our Stars seem dry and restrained by comparison.
Slow-burning but very powerful.
A grim story involving a missing woman is competently told, but there is no disguising the utterly routine nature of the material.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In its own gently comical way, Million Dollar Arm plays up the misunderstandings between Hollywood and India -- as well as the mutual fascination.
The latest Sin City is a major let-down after the brilliance of the original film in 2005.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Fela died in the late 1990s but Gibney has assembled plenty of footage of him performing, and he makes a convincing case for him as both a political and a musical visionary (and a relentless womaniser).
Birdman, though, becomes funnier and more poignant the longer it lasts.
The film is funny, if predictable, about such subjects as motorway traffic jams, sibling rivalry and family feuding.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film, though, is as erratic as Tammy's driving, veering dangerously from gross-out comedy to rank sentimentality with no real sense of where it is headed.
[A] cheerful but cheesy Australia-set musical comedy.
For all its dissonances, Frank is provocative and affecting.
There is some beautiful imagery along the way but the conceit seems forced.
Fashion docs are often shallow in the extreme but this one is as much about fighting back against the ravages of time as it is about air kissing -- and is all the stronger as a result.
Rhys is a droll raconteur who sees the absurdity both in his own quest and that of John Evans before him.
It's all fun in its own (by now) very far-fetched way but reinforces the sense that Godzilla movies will never fully be able to transcend their own innate, cheesy preposterousness.
For all its seeming superficiality, this is a film of considerable formal sophistication.
The problem here is an absurdly convoluted screenplay that leaps back and forth in time in a manner that is both confusing and increasingly irritating.

It is worth remembering that John Wayne, an actor almost as inexpressive as he is, did much of his finest work at the tail end of his career. Sadly, post-gubernator Arnie hasn't yet found his equivalents to True Grit or El Dorado.
Jia Zhangke's brilliantly observed A Touch of Sin paints a bleak and violent picture of a contemporary China in which corruption is endemic.
Its richness lies in the complexity of its characterisation.
Stacie Passon's drama is like Luis Buñuel's Belle de Jour without much of the humour or surrealism.
This may be a romanticised account but it makes a persuasive case for its subject and makes us understand why, before his fall from grace, he was so adored by every rung of Italian society.
movie_title: Pantani: The Accidental Death Of A Cyclist (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mike Leigh's biopic of JMW Turner is a rambling, richly detailed character study with a magnificent central performance from Timothy Spall.
The problem is that audiences are likely to become as fed up with the murderous lovers (Oscar Isaac, Elizabeth Olsen) as they become with each other.
It has some of the satirical flavour of Nathanael West's Day Of The Locust and some of the warped, dream-like feel of David Lynch's Mulholland Drive.
The film makes us admire him but there is little here of the excitement, pathos and despair that you find in the stories of climbers such as George Mallory and Joe Simpson.
Yasujiro Ozu's final film, re-released in a restored version, is a stately, slow-burning but very moving family drama.
The director Amat Escalante shows plenty of visual flair but his detached, matter-of-fact approach to the suffering endured by his protagonists becomes alienating.
Auteuil, looking jowly and weatherbeaten, brings bafflement and pathos to his role as the man suddenly consumed by self-loathing.
The animation is efficient but bland. The characters have all the expressiveness of plastic dolls.
The film has a defiance and humour reminiscent of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. It's far more uplifting than its subject matter might suggest.
Magic Magic is skewered on the horns of a dilemma, uncertain whether it's a horror film or a psychological drama -- and it doesn't work especially well as either.
The film, evocatively shot by John Conroy and with a haunting score by Andrew Hewitt, moves gracefully between periods in its protagonist's life and captures his sense of yearning and loss.
Knight elicits an exceptional performance from Hardy as a man whose extraordinary self-discipline belies his seething inner turmoil.
The plotting is predictable, the cameo from Nicki Minaj is pointless and some of the humour is sadistic in the extreme, but the film yields at least a few chuckles along the way.
Tracks is a stirring and beautifully shot account of the author Robyn Davidson's real-life journey by camel across the Australian outback.
[We get] the nagging feeling that the film-makers, like their protagonists, aren't at all sure where they are going or why.
