If The Wind Rises is Miyazaki's final feature, it marks a suitably rich and strange exit for one of the giants of Japanese cinema.
The film is also grimly compelling on a dramatic level as an account of a family struggling desperately for survival.
movie_title: An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The doc deals sensitively with the extraordinary circumstances of her childhood and features illuminating contributions from journalists and fellow photographers.
A very bloody film noir, directed with tremendous ingenuity by Jeremy Saulnier, Blue Ruin benefits from its pared-down style and macabre humour.
Sharply directed and with effective comic performances from Seth Rogen and Zac Efron, it has a wit and even an occasional tenderness that belie its near-constant crudity.
A reminder both of [Kubrick's] extraordinary formal virtuosity and his powers as a satirist.
Willow Creek is yet another found-footage horror film but it's a fresh and engaging one, combining tongue-in-cheek humour with some genuinely creepy moments.
This is a well-observed drama, which acknowledges the war photographer's selfishness as well as her courage and single-mindedness.
A nasty streak of casual sexism runs through an already unpleasant and absurdly far-fetched film.
The film may be set in the sunny Mediterranean but its interiors are as darkly lit as those in any film noir.
[A] gently whimsical time-travel yarn.
Kathleen Hanna, former lead singer of Bikini Kill, comes across as an inspirational figure in Sini Anderson's rousing documentary.
Jimmy's Hall is is one of the sunniest, most optimistic films in the Ken Loach canon.
Nick Nevern's spoof of football hooligan films doesn't seem that different from the films it is parodying -- but maybe that's the point of the joke.
Eastwood's film version is a classy affair that goes beyond schmaltz and nostalgia (although it has its fair share of both of these.) One of its pleasures is its recreation of post-war America.
This is a difficult film, but made with impressive formal rigour.
The film slowly turns into the kind of manipulative, lachrymose melodrama that Hazel herself professes to detest.
There is an eerie, ghostly quality to Fei Wu's classic 1948 melodrama.
The subject matter is downbeat but Goodison, helped by a likeable young cast, brings moments of humour and lyricism to the storytelling.
Miss Violence is a grim tale of family dysfunction that also stands as an allegory about moral and economic decline in Greek society.
Toby Amies' fascinating, very touching documentary profiles the eccentric exhibitionist Drako Oho Zarhazar at the end of his life.
This engaging French comedy has Fanny Ardant in Mrs Robinson mode as an improbably glamorous retired dentist who has an affair with a younger man.
The director McG seems uncertain whether he should concentrate on the action or the family drama.
There is no attempt to make Charlotte remotely sympathetic... This makes it hard to root for her, or to warm to the film in spite of the grimly effective way in which it is constructed.
It works equally well as a Huckleberry Finn-like adventure story and as a brutal realist drama highlighting the exploitation of young migrants.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film-makers (who also directed Streetdance) strike a frantic tempo but Walking on Sunshine is still often like treading through treacle.
Individual sequences are brilliantly staged and shot but the film still has the feel of a formal exercise and the plot abounds in loose ends.
Seve is moving in a way that sports movies rarely are -- and there is also some humour along the way.
Jon Favreau's enjoyable and good-natured farce is a rarity in that (as its title tells us) it takes a chef as its central character and treats his profession with something approaching respect.
Klapisch has a tremendous cast and an enjoyably freewheeling approach to his subject matter.
Taken as a whimsical but fiery romantic comedy, it has easily enough charm to get away with its own idiosyncrasies.
The film, adapted from Reif Larsen's novel, is beautifully shot in the Jeunet manner.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is a strangely unsatisfactory affair that doesn't quite work either as a documentary-style reconstruction, a brooding thriller or a courtroom drama.

Welcome to New York is squalid and joyless fare. Depardieu's performance doesn't achieve tragic grandeur but it is far more complex and moving than seemed remotely possible in the orgy scenes that open the movie.
Between the slapstick, pointless celebrity cameos, in-jokes and steady stream of feeble puns, the violence is surprisingly graphic.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film is never quite as scary as might have been anticipated. At least, there are plenty of incidental pleasures along the way.

Torben Betts' screenplay for this engaging, quintessentially British road/rambling movie combines knockabout comedy with surprisingly bleak observations about the way the men's lives have all veered off course.

Like Emil Jannings in thrall to Marlene Dietrich in The Blue Angel, Amalric's director is a figure of comedy and pity -- and seems to relish his own sexual humiliation at the hands of this unlikely Venus.
Abu-Assad is simply reflecting the ever-changing nature of his characters' daily lives in a fraught and strange environment in which betrayal has become endemic.
[A] low-key, workmanlike documentary.
The Icelandic director Benedikt Erlingsson's debut feature is a wondrously strange affair, full of beautiful imagery of Icelandic horses set against rugged, frozen backdrops.
At its best, Edge Of Tomorrow has the same fatalistic humour that characterised Groundhog Day. At its worst, it is both repetitive and plain ridiculous.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: E L Katz's film delivers exactly what the title promises. It is a very bloody, very violent fairground ride of a movie that ratchets up the tension as its two hapless anti-heroes compete desperately for money.
Randomly structured and seemingly semi-improvised, it makes laborious viewing.
movie_title: Jolene: The Indie Folk Star Movie (Benny & Jolene) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A grim cautionary tale.
Brilliantly observed and very moving.
The film-makers do an excellent job of conveying the sheer reckless thrill of racing.
With Belle, Asante has succeeded in making a sweeping costume drama that confronts questions of race and gender head on -- something that Merchant Ivory films rarely managed to do.
The film's sometimes downbeat tone can't help but evoke memories of Philip Larkin's The Whitsun Weddings.

For all its self-reflexive jokes, 22 Jump Street is a very traditional affair that offers audiences the same pleasures as Laurel and Hardy, Abbott and Costello or even Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin films.
An engaging and sometimes witty coming-of-age story, it is a patch above some of Sandler's recent live-action films.
Shawn Levy's comedy-drama about a grieving American family is too smug and sanctimonious to take advantage of its top-notch cast.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As an action movie, Spectre is every bit the equal of its predecessor, Skyfall. For at least half its running time, this is as good as Bond gets -- a rip-roaring and very stylishly made thriller with tremendous production values.
It's a superb piece of work, beautiful and enigmatic.
[Kaurismaki's] new feature The Other Side Of Hope is a typically deadpan and brilliantly observed comic study of the plight of a fictional asylum seeker in Finland.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bodily functions are to the fore in excruciating new family comedy Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wonderstruck has its grace notes but there aren't quite enough of them.

Gadot plays Diana in appealing fashion. For all her strength and prowess, she is an innocent, even comic figure, who simply can't understand the cynicism, politicking, and violence of the humans she encounters.
In their rush to provide a happy ending, the filmmakers lose sight of many of their own supporting characters and fill the plot with far too many artificial sweeteners.
The writing here is sometimes arch and laboured but Allam puts across even the most stilted lines with enormous brio.

No one makes family melodramas quite like Japanese director Hirokazu Koreeda. His style is deceptively low key and matter of fact even as he deals with seismic moments in the lives of his protagonists.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Claude Barras' Oscar-nominated stop-motion animated feature is as poignant and as well observed a film about the darker side of childhood as you could ever hope to see.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Whenever the action stops, though, the film becomes derivative and empty headed, Strip away the bandages and there really isn't very much here at all.
Writer-director Michell tells an at times overheated story in a cool and stylish way.
We're in a cut-throat world of politics and schmoozing but the wistful music and playful chapter titles give the film the feel of a folk tale or of a slightly darker version of a Woody Allen comedy.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Director Craig Johnson (who also dealt with middle aged angst in his previous film, The Skeleton Twins) has a nicely matter of fact way of showing Wilson's tribulations.
Modern-day Christian parables don't come any stodgier or more syrupy than this.
Ballerina is at its best in the dancing scenes, which are animated with verve and realism, with every leap and pirouette finely rendered.
Baywatch is an exercise is self-reflexive irony and kitsch. It's mocking the original TV series -- which seems pretty pointless given that the series was tongue in cheek anyway.
It's a case of Carry On Jean-Luc Godard in this very lightweight comic film dramatising key moments in the life of the sacred monster of French New Wave cinema.
A surprisingly sprightly and enjoyable late entry in the Pirates Of The Caribbean franchise.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is on the lengthy side and sometimes has a sour taste but it boasts one of Dustin Hoffman's best performances in recent years -- and a very poignant one too, a long way from Happy Gilmour-like goofiness, from Adam Sandler.
This is a film full of grace notes -- self-contained scenes that play like mini-symphonies.
William Oldroyd's riveting debut feature Lady Macbeth plays like a cross between Wuthering Heights and The Postman Always Rings Twice.
The comedy, like its hapless actor and TV detective hero Richard Thorncroft (Julian Barratt of TV's The Mighty Boosh), manages by turns both to be funny and charming and seedy and dispiriting.
A fascinating and surprisingly dramatic and topical affair.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a bizarre endeavour, a rambling tale whose purpose, in spite of its title, is very hard to work out.
Unlocked rattles along at a very brisk pace and is full of action set-pieces.
In its portrayal of cops on the take, Sleepless often resembles an episode of TV's The Shield.

The strength of the documentary lies in the skill with which Broomfield combines a cautionary showbiz tale with a probing analysis of race, class, gender and celebrity. The structure here is akin to that of a detective story.
The real pleasure of the film comes from Chastain's wonderfully acerbic and uninhibited performance.
We can spot from the outset just which way the film is headed but just because we can see punches coming, that doesn't mean they stop from landing.
You can feel the mud squelching under your feet as you watch Hope Dickson Leach's impressive if very dour and dark debut feature, The Levelling.
Amid all the sound and fury, it takes a while to realise that actually not very much is happening here at all.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's the construction, not the performances, which undermines The Secret Scripture.
This isn't so much a coherent movie as a lot of comedy sketches strung together. While Schumer turns out to be a dead-eyed shot, the film itself has a very wayward aim.
The film has a quietly devastating charge.

She is supposed to be a self-pitying near alcoholic who can't take control of her own life. Hathaway, though, is such a strong screen presence that it's hard to believe in her as such a weak and needy type.
It's one of his most heartfelt films, beautifully made and very moving in its own quiet, self-effacing way.
Cox gives a fascinating performance even if the film itself is on the lugubrious side.

This is a benign and good natured film. Even at the most oppressive moments, there will always be a wisecrack. The smart ass humour here is crucial. Without it, the film would have risked seeming too dry and too maudlin by turns.
What gives Destination Unknown its power is the focus on the trauma endured by the survivors.
At times, you suspect the filmmakers are throwing in humour, action and pathos simply as a way to distract from the extreme pessimism that's really at the core of their story.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Nolan] has managed to combine the epic and the intimate. We are a long way from next year's Oscars but Dunkirk must surely already be a frontrunner.
Scribe is an atmospheric but overwrought French conspiracy thriller.

This isn't exactly a critical portrait of its subject but it's an affectionate and informative one which highlights Di Palma's key creative role in the work of Antonioni and Woody Allen in particular.
movie_title: Water and Sugar: Carlo Di Palma, the Colours of Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Captain Underpants is wondrously inane and bizarre entertainment.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary can't provide an upbeat finale. Instead, it shows how its subjects try to carry on living their lives in spite of the sacrifices they've had to make.
What Girls Trip does have going for it is an irrepressible energy and an absolute lack of embarrassment about its own crudity and pants down humour.
This is Southern Gothic at its most lush and delirious. It is also very comic in its own macabre way. Coppola conjures up a wonderfully fervid atmosphere.
Given the constraints the filmmakers have imposed on themselves, this is a remarkably gripping affair.
47 Metres Down is competently enough made but suffers from a plot almost as rickety as the ancient cage in which the two sisters descend into the deep to view the sharks.
One of the glories of the film is its ability to find comic details in the most bleak and oppressive situations.
A crash course in both the worst and best of French director Luc Besson, Valerian looks spectacular but its storytelling proves muddled
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Emoji Movie is based on an idea which must have seemed very clever in theory but turns out to be cumbersome in practice.
As an account of the Adrian Mole-like growing pains of the depressive young would-be artist, the film makes surprisingly poignant viewing.
Aisling Walsh knows how to balance the comedy and the pathos as she takes us through her subject's life and chronicles her unlikely emergence as an artist.
Sports documentaries tend to be very predictable. Williams surprises us by coming at its subject matter from an unlikely perspective.
Writer-director Ben Young has made a very striking but self-conscious debut feature -- one in which the shooting style shifts from low key naturalism to extreme stylisation.

There have been many films about middle-aged angst and disappointment but what makes Argyris Papadimitropoulos' Suntan so striking is that it is set in the middle of August on a baking hot Greek island, full of tourists out to have a good time.
Cars 3 itself is a sprightly and likeable film because it shares Lightning's self-effacing qualities and his nostalgic fondness for looking at life through the rear view mirror.
In its own sombre, ritualistic way, the film makes compelling viewing.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At times, it feels like an upmarket municipal tourist video, shot in the style of Chris Marker or Patrick Keiller. It's a soothing experience, though, and one that certainly highlights the beauty of the city it is showcasing.
Michael Bay is back with another mammoth budget to throw at the screen in the latest Transformers monstrosity.
Mike Nichols' film makes such beguiling viewing largely because of Hoffman's performance as Benjamin, which combines humour, boredom and panic in equal measure.
The drawback here is the utter lack of pungency. This film doesn't smell real at all.
The Book Of Henry is a very bizarre affair, stuck in treacherous waters between kids' movie, terminal illness melodrama and hardboiled film noir.

It's a measure of Isabelle Huppert's versatility that she can switch from her searing, Oscar-nominated performance as the rape victim in Paul Verhoeven's psychodrama Elle to playing a long-forgotten pop singer in this sweet-natured little fable.

In a summer of yet more synthetic blockbusters, Baby Driver feels entirely original. This is jukebox filmmaking, a wildly energetic movie whose characters behave in line with the songs that fill its soundtrack.
A fascinating, very intimate portrait of the artist and filmmaker in which we hear Lynch talk through key formative moments his life in stream of consciousness fashion.

[It's] random in the extreme in structure but it is also wildly inventive, full of visual and verbal gags, and very good natured too. The energy levels never dip and each new set-piece turns out to even more bizarre and original than its predecessor.
A Man Called Ove is maudlin and sugary but it offers the same pleasures as all those other books and films about grumpy old men looking for redemption.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Alone In Berlin distinctive is the form the resistance takes... It's about an ordinary middle-aged German couple who express their disgust for the regime by writing postcards. Stories about heroism don't come any more understated.
Tom Holland's Peter Parker, one of the liveliest characters in last year's Captain America: Civil War, now has an entire movie devoted to him - one with plenty of youthful snap and crackle.
This is certainly a bleak story but it's also a rich and very nuanced one.
You can tell almost exactly how matters will end but when it comes to pathos, sharp-eyed observation and barbed humour, The Midwife certainly delivers.
This isn't a very distinguished film but it's likely to be remembered for its central performance.
"Nothing felt real," Mara laments at the start of Song To Song. That, sadly, is an observation that can just as well be aimed at the movie as a whole.
One of the most impressive elements in a very likeable documentary is the balance Torun strikes between analysis and affection in her approach toward her feline protagonists.
The film is absorbing enough to watch in its own TV mini-series-like way but it also feels strangely melodramatic. It doesn't help that the dialogue is often so arch.
The second Guardians Of The Galaxy is Marvel Studios near its best: spectacular, funny and with a very likeable self-mocking quality.
[An] entertaining and insightful romantic drama.
Playful and profound by turns, it spins a complex and multi-layered story from what seems to be a simple premise.
Is it an anti-capitalist parable or a shaggy dog story? It is never clear what intentions lie behind Stephen Gaghan's new film, which only glitters very intermittently.
[Jovovich] indestructibility explains why there is so little dramatic tension.
This is a morbid but very original film which manages both to be reflective and dramatic.
The LEGO Batman Movie is a tremendously witty and self-reflexive affair that probes far more deeply into the Caped Crusader's wounded psyche than most live-action movies.
The film is very good at capturing the camaraderie of the soldiers -- and the sometimes desperate way in which they rely on one another.
It is very morbid fare, but Lowe combines the Dario Argento-like bloodletting with a very British, very deadpan wit.
Loving is a quiet film but a powerful and uplifting one -- an intimate domestic drama in which the protagonists themselves hardly seem to notice their own historical roles.
This feels more like a record of a stage performance than a film in its own right. That, though, doesn't lessen its impact in the slightest or take away from the searing brilliance of the two leads.
Fifty Shades Darker is an ordeal to watch not because of its gothic eroticism but because of its utter blandness.
You won't find a more sensitively rendered, evocative, or surprising coming-of-age film than Barry Jenkins's Moonlight.
Given that it had a huge budget as well as the combined expertise of Hollywood and China behind it, The Great Wall is a surprisingly primitive and clunky affair.
This is an immensely likeable film and one that draws overdue attention to a story that has been neglected for far too long.
One fundamental problem is that John Wick is well-nigh indestructible. That means the element of threat simply isn't there.
It is a surprisingly nuanced and barbed look at the American Dream and its flip side.

Logan is a Marvel movie with a bit of soul and some true grit. Presumed to be the final outing for Wolverine, it plays more like a late period John Wayne western than it does like a conventional superhero film.
You won't see any other film this year that tries as hard to get under the skin of its characters as Mike Mills' 20th Century Women. That's both its glory and what makes it sometimes such a trial.

A Cure For Wellness seems at times like one of Tim Burton's darker offerings but it conspicuously lacks the charm and wit that Burton invariably brings to his work. The film takes itself very seriously - and that's part of the problem.

Mel Gibson's Hacksaw Ridge is one of the best Second World War movies since Terrence Malick's The Thin Red Line. It is also a wildly contradictory affair, combining folksiness with a pathological quality.
Rebecca Hall gives an excellent performance as Christine, one that captures the character's mix of insecurity and ambition, her extreme reticence and her desire to be liked.
Its extraordinary power lies in the interweaving of the fantastical and the everyday.
[Byrne is] an excellent subject for a film - full of colourful anecdotes about his excesses and brattish behaviour but perplexed and pained by his own failure
In its own demolition derby-like way, the film has a certain outlandish charm. Its script, though, makes no sense whatsoever.
A movie that can't work out whether it is a swashbuckling romp or a dystopian sci-fi drama.
Gibney plays up the thriller elements of his story.
Endless Poetry may be uneven but it shows that Jodorowsky's ability to startle us with both his lyricism and his perversity isn't impaired in the slightest.
That Manchester By The Sea is so absorbing is down to Lonergan's painstaking directorial style and to a superb Method-style performance from the lead actor.
As a courtroom drama, Denial is always intriguing.
Writer-director Peter Foott fills the film with slapstick and with plenty of scabrous, witty dialogue.
Live By Night is as clunky in its exposition as it is gorgeous in its craftsmanship.
It's the incongruity of the Jackie Kennedy story told in Pablo Larrain's Jackie that makes the film so compelling.
It hasn't aged in the slightest.
For much of its running time, the film is tense and genuinely intriguing.
The film is moving enough in its own terms but lacks the depth and complexity that might have been expected.
What's so impressive about T2 is how skilfully it manages to stay true to the spirit of the original while acknowledging just how much has changed in the intervening years.
It's cheery, toe tapping fare that kids are bound to enjoy and that has enough nostalgia and in-jokes to keep the adults happy enough too.
Blood Wars is the fifth installment in the Underworld series. It is likely to prove largely incomprehensible to anyone who hasn't seen the previous four.
When the relationships between the leading characters are all so superficial and everyone is deceiving everyone else, it is very hard to engage emotionally with the movie.
The first half hour of Patriots Day is riveting.

This is an illuminating and moving film which shows Best at his seediest and most pathetic but never loses sight of the brilliance that made the homesick kid from Belfast into football's first superstar.
Dito Montiel's Man Down is a well-meaning but very confused drama exploring post-traumatic stress and the plight of US soldiers "coming home."
Graduation is utterly compelling in spite of a seemingly downbeat story.
Ben Wheatley's cartoonishly violent Free Fire begins with such zest that it is all the more dispiriting how quickly it loses its way.
Ghost In The Shell might not stack up plot-wise but what it does reinforce is Scarlett Johansson's status as one of the great stars of her era.

The story is an unholy mish-mash between saccharine family melodrama and anarchic Loony Tunes-style farce. It's a big, gooey mess of a movie, without the gags or visual ingenuity to compensate for its infantile premise.

You could easily imagine a series being spun off based around Riz Ahmed's character. As a self-contained story, though, the film is frustrating. There's so much going on around the edges that the main investigation seems almost an afterthought.
This is a determinedly playful, magical realist-style yarn.
The storytelling style here is far less zany and irreverent than in the typical Pixar film or Lego Movie. The voice cast is intriguing enough but a certain soppy blandness comes with the territory.
The shock tactics can verge on the prurient but even in the most extreme moments, the film never loses sight of character.
There is a hint of old Ealing comedies in Ronnie Thompson's likeable if very undercharged telling of the story of the 2015 Hatton Garden jewellery/safety deposit box heist.
The film is every bit as silly and enjoyable as its predecessors.
What begins as a nostalgic and humdrum family drama grows more and more compelling the darker it becomes.
A complex and wonderfully decadent erotic melodrama.
For all the striving for epic grandeur, the film feels like a chamber piece.
This is a determinedly oddball film but it's one made with plenty of energy. At least, Beatty, at this very advanced stage in his career, doesn't appear to have lost any of his old youthful zest.
It has the same low key naturalism and idiosyncratic humour found in classic new wave movies like A Blonde In Love and Closely Observed Trains.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Baldwin was writing more than 30 years ago. Not so much has changed since then. Even so, I Am Not Your Negro isn't as pessimistic as its downbeat tone suggests it should be. Baldwin's commentary is intended to provoke, not to induce despair.
This may be a filmed play but Dolan's graceful treatment of the material ensures that it rarely feels too stagy or claustrophobic.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Another Mother's Son] feels more like a TV movie than anything cinematic.
Gorgeously shot by Darius Khondji, it manages the feat of making the English and Irish-set scenes look just as rich and strange as those that unfold far down the Amazon.
Fist Fight is a crude and foul-mouthed comedy whose most notable feature is its utter pessimism about the American high school system.
It has a compelling and charismatic performance from Michael Fassbender but suffers from an identity problem.
Watching the film, you feel a depth of understanding and sympathy for the characters that simply wouldn't be there in a more conventional, plot-driven movie.
Viceroy's House is at its best when the pomp and circumstance is kept at bay and the film is allowed to capture the everyday reality of life in the palace just before the British leave.
It's certainly not a beast of a movie but it's not a beauty either.
The pleasure of the film, directed with plenty of vigour by Jordan Vogt-Roberts, lies in its absolute refusal to take itself remotely seriously.
The pessimism of Catfight is belied by the very lively performances from the two leads.
This is pulsating storytelling, suspenseful and often very stylish too.

Even in the film's most far-fetched moments, Biller has trenchant points to make about conservative, middle-class America's fear of female sexuality and the double standards that apply to men and women's romantic behaviour.
There is not a single moment in the entire movie in which we are able to guess what [Huppert] will do next -- and that's what makes Elle such a wild and surprising ride.
In Farhadi's universe, ambiguity reigns.
The film is moving and insightful because it is more concerned with being honest than with being uplifting.
Wolves At The Door is a repellent, misconceived, and pointless film.
This is a movie in which brilliance and banality sit side-by-side but one in which Stewart always shines.
Witty, trenchant, very topical, sometimes utterly bloodcurdling but always with plenty of polemical points to make.

Daniel Espinosa's new feature provides incontrovertible proof that, well over three decades after that polyp-like succubus exploded out of John Hurt's stomach in Ridley Scott's Alien, the sci-fi horror film is alive and well.

The documentary highlights [Polunin's] brilliance as a performer but its real richness lies in its frank and painful account of just what it took for him to reach the top and of his doubt about what to do once he got there.
As a film about the political intricacies of the Korean war, it's an utter failure but as a boys' own adventure romp, full of gunfire and explosions, it just about passes muster.
There will be plenty who will take a masochistic pleasure in seeing [Annabelle] return as soon as possible.
With her instincts as a storyteller, Lipitz emphasises the grimmer elements so that the pay-off is all the more gratifying.
The film doesn't skimp on the spectacle either and offers an intriguing account of the early days of the American travelling circus. This, though, is a patchy affair.
... a good natured but one-dimensional sequel to the 1995 film starring Robin Williams.
... it's a pity that the storytelling in Pitch Perfect 3 is so absolutely off key.
Christian O'Reilly's screenplay combines elements from the typical feelgood drama with harsher insights into the lives of the protagonists.
Its main recommendation, aside from the brilliance of Chastain, is Sorkin's ingeniously crafted screenplay.
It remains as mysterious and troubling now as it ever was.
Unfortunately, the results are laughable.
Some of its best scenes are its most absurd ones, in which Plummer's Getty behaves with a grotesque meanness.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you want to deal with the most primal emotions in the most rugged settings, to combine action and soul-searching, this is still the genre to turn to first.
[Ben Stiller] gives an appealing performance in a very familiar type of role in writer-director Mike White's comedy-drama, Brad's Status.
The brilliant Hungarian director Kornel Mundruczo's latest feature sits uncomfortably between political allegory and thriller.
When it comes to Zen and the art of movie making, Marvel's Doctor Strange is much more fun than this.
This isn't an uncritical celebration of British bulldog spirit but a nuanced portrait of Churchill at a key point early in the war.
It's an eccentric, wildly entertaining and very inventive affair which combines live performance and music hall references with documentary elements.
It doesn't make for cheerful viewing but, in its own downbeat way, A Woman's Life makes absorbing filmmaking.
Jia Zhangke's Mountains May Depart might best be described as an intimate epic.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: On many levels, Shot Caller makes no sense whatsoever.

In his debut feature, director Daniel Rezende (a renowned editor) foregrounds the sheer chutzpah and energy of his protagonist but the latter part of the film is far less invigorating than the beginning.
movie_title: Bingo: The King of the Mornings (Bingo - O rei das manhãs) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For all the complexity of the sub-plots, the storyline is reassuringly familiar.
Ferrell fans will enjoy Daddy's Home 2 but others will find its gloopy sentimentality very hard indeed to digest.
Writer-director Eliza Hittman's Beach Rats is a Brooklyn-set coming of age story made with a gritty lyricism bound to provoke comparisons with the work of French director Claire Denis.
The film throws in anarchic physical comedy with picture postcard-style imagery of Paris at its most alluring. It's a generally winning combination.
In a performance tinged with comedy and pathos, Carrell captures Riggs's sleaziness, his chutzpah and his childlike quality.
It's very soft-centred but succeeds in casting new light on an episode in its subject's much scrutinised life that hasn't been quite as exhaustively examined as one might have expected.
It's a nice irony that one of the worst movies in recent history has enabled James Franco to make one of the best films in his own chequered career.
Stephen Chbosky's Wonder is sharply enough written and performed to overcome its own very schmaltzy premise.
There is much here to relish but the film also often feels digressive and rambling, uncertain as to whether its main focus should be on the music or the life.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: We've seen similar characters in countless other dramas and soap operas but their stories have never been told in as mysterious a way as they are here.
Stronger is at its best in its harshest moments, when it acknowledges the contradictions in its hero's story and portrays his bitterness and self-loathing as well as his courage.
Ai Weiwei's magnificent documentary stands as a companion piece to the BBC's series, Exodus: Our Journey To Europe.
You can see the points [director Oren] Moverman is trying to make, but it's just a pity that the dialogue isn't sharper and that the protagonists are so thoroughly unsympathetic.
Against the odds, Brigsby never descends into cynicism.
Whatever pickle he gets himself in, we can't help but root for Menashe.
... an exploitative, silly and thoroughly unpleasant affair, with a premise that defies credibility.
We are encouraged not to think too hard about what the matador really does with his sword and to enjoy the good natured high jinks the film provides instead.
We can guess exactly how the story will unfold but that doesn't lessen the humour or the gentle pathos.
This is a love story, a thriller and a social realist drama all at once.
[Garrel] keeps matters light and tells the story of his three protagonists' ever more complicated and contradictory love lives with gentle and beguiling humour.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: The Post manages the feat of being nostalgic and topical.

What does emerge from every account is that Tonya Harding was a force of nature, single-minded, very tough and always ready to keep on fighting, even if she had the fatalistic view that people from her background simply weren't allowed to become winners.
This is a powerful film with a grinding intensity about it. Light relief it isn't but Dark River still has quite an impact.
The actors clearly know their moves.
Finding Your Feet touches on some dark subjects - Alzheimer's, depression, cancer - but somehow always manages to keep up its irrepressibly cheery and inane mood.
The film has its idiosyncrasies and obvious weaknesses but is frank and utterly relentless in the way it probes into the emotional lives of its three main characters.
Domenika may be made to suffer but she dishes out the violence as well.
The raucous energy of the early scenes isn't sustained and the film becomes increasingly repetitious and silly. The comedy elements here work far better than the thriller ones.
Anderson is clearly a dog lover himself and his film is bound to appeal to anyone who shares his passion. All in all, the film is quite a treat.

It manages the feat of remaining a moody and atmospheric private eye-style mystery while offering more insight into the final days of Mubarak's presidency than any didactic, self-righteous documentary could ever manage.
... a clunky, ungainly and misconceived affair, neither witty nor visually imaginative enough even to begin to compare with the best Hollywood animation.
This is an oedipal drama about shame, guilt and sexual betrayal. Allen throws in a few gags - but not very many.
We have no sense of being preached at but the director's indignation and bewilderment at the plight of men like Sam is always self-evident. Hamilton Morris plays Sam with dignity and wry fatalism.
Walk Like a Panther is another in the increasingly long list of films about likeable British underdogs, fighting back against the odds to save their communities.
It is probably best not to look for the deeper meanings in the plot and to regard Mom & Dad as a new twist on an old-fashioned survival story.
[director Lynne] Ramsay creates many memorable images and evokes a disorienting atmosphere.
The film, scripted by John Hodge of Trainspotting fame, is skillful in the way it gives a modern-day story about cheating in sport a mythic feel.
Regardless of the story's sexual politics, Marina is the type of movie heroine that any audience will root for (one reason why it has secured an Oscar nomination).
... a fascinating affair, both as a natural history film and as a closely focused study of a woman who lived her own real-life version of The Jungle Book.
Polish director Pawel Lozinski's film is an intriguing but deceptive affair, straddling the lines between documentary and drama.
movie_title: You Have No Idea How Much I Love You (Nawet nie wiesz, jak bardzo cie kocham) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It isn't remotely subtle.
... Coco is another triumph for Pixar...
Early Man isn't the flashiest animated feature that you'll see this year but it is certainly the most likeable.
12 Strong combines formidable technique with a very simple-minded and jingoistic perspective on the American war on terror.
The Maze Runner trilogy comes to an end in messy but spectacular fashion in this very convoluted final instalment.
Linklater allows Cranston, Carrell and Fishburne to give performances of a richness and depth that you won't find in their more obviously crowd-pleasing movies.
Whatever the cynicism of the adults, the kids who swarm around the travelling shows still believe in the wonder of cinema. So do the directors of this poignant, funny and insightful film.
The pleasure here lies in the unpredictability of Paul Thomas Anderson's approach, his ability and that of his actors to surprise us with every new stitch of the movie.
Where the film does succeed is in underlining its subject's credentials as an artist.
It ends in a very unsatisfactory way but that doesn't take away from the mercurial originality of Washington's performance.
It's hard to think of any recent thriller as derivative as Den Of Thieves.

The Black Panther is not only one of the most entertaining recent superhero films but has an intelligence and a political dimension that such inchoate offerings as Suicide Squad and Justice League completely lacked.
The film is as much about Britishness, class and codes of honour as it is about sailing.

Loveless isn't cheerful viewing at all but it is virtuoso filmmaking from one of the few contemporary directors whose work bears comparison with that of the great auteurs from an older era in arthouse cinema.
Some of the visual gags are witty enough but for audiences spoilt in recent times by the gleaming brilliance of Pixar and Aardman animated features, this is very thin gruel.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Director James Foley has made some decent thrillers in his time but simply can't find a way to whip up any dramatic interest here whatsoever.
Writer-director Gerwig manages brilliantly the delicate feat of portraying the vulnerabilities and eccentricities of the townsfolk without patronising them.
This version of Journey's End may not offer any new perspectives into its subject matter but it is made with a commitment and intensity that stop it from ever seeming old fashioned.
Dalglish is still guarded but emerges as a reflective, perceptive and dryly humorous figure with an intensely competitive streak.
89 strikes a nice line between sporting bombast and self-deprecating humour.
The Safdie brothers' crime thriller Good Time is a chaotic, wildly inventive but increasingly self-indulgent affair.
It's an American thriller that will certainly appeal to fans of Scandinavian noir.
What makes this film so distinctive and so evocative is youthful innocence of the protagonists in the face of grinning evil.
The Work makes gruelling viewing at times - it's more like psychotherapy than entertainment - but, by the end, viewers will feel as if they've been on the same rewarding journey as the subjects.
As in Ingmar Bergman's Shame (1968), [Writer/Director Philippe Van Leeuw] is exploring how quickly the veneer of civilisation can be stripped away when people are forced to fight for survival.

The veteran Labour MP Dennis Skinner... emerges as a far more complex and sympathetic figure in this documentary than he appears when he is haranguing Tories and talking class warfare during House of Commons debates.
movie_title: Dennis Skinner: Nature of the Beast (2017)

movie_review_blurb: American Assassin looks as if it is intended as the first in a series but there's nothing here which we haven't seen countless times before in Jason Bourne or Jack Reacher stories or that justifies a new movie.
The Villainess is a wonderfully lurid and overcooked thriller with a plot so melodramatic that you half suspect the filmmakers borrowed it from an opera.
Aronofksy shows plenty of visual flair. That, though, doesn't excuse the self-indulgence and mounting silliness of the filmmaking here.

The film doesn't make much sense and the animation isn't especially sophisticated but the young kids at whom it is aimed should warm to its cheery tone while the adults might appreciate its anarchic streak and some of its off-the-wall humour.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Dame Judi Dench] is haughty and imperious when she needs to be but brings quiet humour and tenderness to the role too.

One of the strengths of First They Killed My Father is its matter of fact quality. Only very late on does Jolie indulge in the kind of melodramatic flourishes you'd expect in a Hollywood movie on the same subject.
Lasting for well over two hours, this is a gilded hamster wheel of a movie.
Borg McEnroe is informative and well-acted but also very predictable.
The film... is beautifully played by its two leads and has a wonderfully barbed and unsettling quality that you will never find in any Hollywood romcom.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: ... the film celebrates their resilience and irrepressible good humour in the face of the priggish menfolk who surround them.
The knowledge of the upheavals that Egypt has experienced in the intervening years only adds to the poignancy here.
movie_title: In the Last Days of the City (Akher ayam el madina) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: The tempo here is different to that of the westerns that clearly inspired the director. The film is reflective and lyrical.

Goodbye Christopher Robin is a real tearjerker with plenty of very maudlin moments but what makes the film so fascinating, and ultimately so moving, is the bleakness that sits alongside the sentimentality.
[Three Billboards] is a startling piece of work: a perverse, comic and tragic revenge story in which all the characters defy our often very low expectations of them.
This is a monster movie but it plays like a Beauty and the Beast-style romance.
The pests are back in this none too ingratiating sequel to the 2014 animated feature.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are no new love affairs, no murders, no conspiracy. As a result, the film risks seeming as undernourished as Giacometti's own spindly, sculpted figurines.
The Hitman's Bodyguard is an infantile and very violent buddy movie that rehashes ideas and serves up characters encountered in countless other action flick.
This is a frustrating film because it never seems certain what story it is trying to tell.
An Inconvenient Sequel is skilfully put together. As in An Inconvenient Truth (2006), lecture material is combined with Gore's reflections on his own private and political life.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is all the more disappointing that The Dark Tower turns out such a dud. All the elements appear to be here.
Tom Cruise gives one of his finest screen performances in American Made, a film which allows the normally clean-cut star to show his delinquent side.
Co-scripted by the Coen brothers, [Suburbicon] is both wildly entertaining in its own macabre, violent fashion, and also very perceptive about racism and hypocrisy in middle-class white America.
In its own polemical way, it is very powerful filmmaking but, as storytelling, it is one-dimensional. There is too much "docu" here and not enough drama.
[Logan Lucky] is not going to win him any Oscars but Soderbergh certainly appears to have recovered his zest for filmmaking.
What can't be denied, though, is the originality of the premise or the sheer verve with which Payne creates his modern-day Lilliput.
Plot wise, Patti Cake$ is straight from the Rocky or Cinderella playbook. The more that Patti is knocked back, the more inevitable it is that her talent will finally shine through.
This is a highly impressive debut feature: bleak and lyrical by turns, and with very fine performances from its two young leads.
Una makes queasy and uncomfortable viewing.
What can never be escaped, though, is the utterly formulaic nature of the storytelling.
The Limehouse Golem is wildly over the top. That's precisely what it is meant to be - and what gives the drama such a kick.
Directors Cary Murnion and Jonathan Milott throw in plenty of explosions, fights and chases to distract us but whenever the action stops, the film begins to seem very silly indeed.
This is a film with its own gentle logic. It's a quiet meditation on life, love, bereavement and the difficulty of letting go.
This is a romantic comedy but one that would need only the very slightest tweaking to be transformed into a home invasion horror movie.
Of course, this is a film about human beings as much as it is one about hens. It works because [Slavko] Martinov has found such lively characters.
... dark and voyeuristic fare with a plot that could easily have been borrowed from one of Brian De Palma's more lurid thrillers.
The jumps themselves are astonishing.
He is a movie hero without a shade of cynicism, one who never loses either his sticky-pawed innocence or his idealism.
Yorgos Lanthimos's surrealistic revenge tragedy is all the more chilling because of its absurdist and macabre humour.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thelma is an intriguing but unwieldy mix between European art-house drama and supernatural horror.
There have been several documentaries about the motor racing world in recent years. This is one of the best.
78/52 is a fascinating affair, bound to appeal to movie lovers and social theorists alike even if it does sometimes seem more like a film studies lecture than a conventional piece of entertainment.
Jones is both fabulous and terrifying.
... a playful, poignant and always surprising account of the birth of Wonder Woman.
Its real subject, it soon turns out, is death, not survival.
The plot doesn't always stack up but the two Joneses combine to create a psychological thriller with an extremely oppressive atmosphere.
... a clever and affecting meditation on memory, bereavement, love and remorse masquerading as a sci-fi movie.
Facetious, tongue-in-cheek humour doesn't help.
Bening's performance is subtle and courageous.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In its own earnest way, it is very moving.
The satire here works so well precisely because it is so accurately observed.
The Florida Project is one of the best films about childhood made anywhere in recent years.
[Emily] Beecham impresses in patches but there is always a sense that she, like the filmmakers, is holding something back and isn't prepared to go all the way.
What makes the film so magical is the extraordinary delicacy, formal daring and insight with which Guadagnino tackles such familiar material.
... just as cutesy and sentimental as you expect it is going to be.
[An] intriguing Russian satire.
Like The Godfather Part II, it's a sequel to a very celebrated film which may actually be better than the original.
... there's an energy and optimism here which belie the grim subject matter and [director Andy] Serkis knows just how to tweak our heart strings when it comes to the final reel.
The real disappointment here is how conventional the storytelling becomes and how little the two leads are challenged in anything other than the most obvious way.
What we are left with is a family saga which is far more dispiriting than uplifting and which often makes very grim viewing.
It reminds us what a limited and one-dimensional politician he was - but also what a consummate performer whenever the cameras were in sight.
On a formal level, this is a subtle and clever piece of work.
Thor: Ragnarok is fun in its own kinetic, comic book fashion but it doesn't have any dramatic urgency whatsoever.
... a very slick slice of Scandinavian noir but one whose plot slaloms become increasingly preposterous.
The Lego Ninjago Movie has its moments... but risks drifting off into inanity in a way that the earlier films in the franchise didn't.
At times, The Party becomes a little glib... This, though, is lively and invigorating filmmaking with an energy that belies its own pessimism.
Director David Bruckner knows how to jolt us out of our seats one moment and to repel us the next but there's nothing here we haven't encountered before...
Iannucci's version of events may be well researched but it still gives us a very British, very witty but facetious version of a dark story which might have been better told by an insider.

In terms of its storyline alone, this is a bit of a potboiler, a typical prison drama, but the dialogue is razor sharp and the performances, especially that of Vince Vaughn, are far more nuanced and poignant than you'd expect.
It is ingeniously structured in its own right, even if some of its plot twists and contortions don't entirely stack up.
For all its satirical elements, I Am Not A Witch retains an air of mystery.
As a piece of handcrafted animation, it provides a welcome contrast to all those movies full of cutesy talking animals turned out by the Hollywood studios.
Why Him? is a very crude and intermittently very entertaining seasonal comedy that plays like an adult version of Meet The Parents.
The result is a perfectly acceptable sequel that should satisfy the die-hard fans of the series while also entertaining newcomers. What it isn't, though, is remotely original.

Passengers delivers plenty of fairground ride-like spectacle. This, though, doesn't begin to atone for its evasive and equivocal storyline or for the mood of phoney optimism that always prevails, even at the very grimmest moments.
As a psychological study of a grief-stricken mother, the film works well enough. When it turns into a tale of demonic possession, it begins to creak.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This enjoyably atrocious action thriller is so inept in parts that you think it must be a spoof.

The only drawbacks to an excellent documentary are the skimpy treatment of Hitchcock's 1930s British work and the lack of diversity among the interviewees. Jones could have included at least one or two female film-makers.
Oren Moverman's observational drama about the day-to-day life of George (Richard Gere), a homeless man in New York, is made with delicacy and insight.
The finale here is about as exciting to watch as an office party on a paintball outing.
The problem is that the craft and artistry are just too laboured and foregrounded.
As a case study in journalism and ethics, the film is intriguing. As drama, it stutters.
This isn't so much a remake of Juan José Campanella's 2009 Oscar winner for Best Foreign Language Film as an utter travesty of it.

The behaviour of the characters stretches credibility. The performances, though, are striking, especially that of Poésy as the young mum assailed by feelings of guilt, doubt, suspicion and hostility as her grasp on reality begins to loosen.
Patricio Guzmán's essay-style documentary is a deceptive but very moving affair.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The problem here is that there is no zest at all to the storytelling.
[High-Rise] is visionary film-making, wildly ambitious, very caustic and hitting the bull's eye of almost every target in its sights.
In an era of bloated blockbusters, 10 Cloverfield Lane is refreshingly pared down -- a chamber piece rather than an epic.

Marguerite is a handsomely shot period affair with all the trimmings. At its core, though, it is a very delicate study of a woman who refuses to accept any of the constraints that her class, gender or lack of talent should place on her.
Barry Levinson's film, loosely inspired by the true story of reality TV show Afghan Star, comes at its subject matter from entirely the wrong direction.

For all the eye-popping spectacle here, the brilliance of some of the action sequences, and the full-blooded performances from Ben Affleck and Henry Cavill as the superheroes, this turns out to be a convoluted affair.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Anomalisa is a reminder that animation can do much more than provide high jinks for a family audience. This is a surprisingly dark film, but it is a lyrical and insightful one. It delves into areas that even the frankest live-action dramas shy away from.
Iona is a lyrical, reflective drama that owes an obvious debt to the film-making of Andrei Tarkovsky and Carl Dreyer.

The storytelling is very perfunctory. Some of the shock tactics are moderately effective but, as the film-makers attempt to combine traditional horror movie elements with insights into the troubled psychology of their heroine, they soon lose their way.

Renzi provides a platform for Gere to act in barnstorming fashion but can't work out what to do with any of the other characters. They tend just to stand embarrassed on the sidelines as Gere holds forth and steals every scene in which he appears.
It deserves success. Moreover it should make stars of Sawyers and Sumpter.
This is one of the Coen brothers' jolliest and most carefree films - quite a surprise considering its subject matter.
Hákonarson has an eye both for the forbidding beauty of the landscapes and for comic detail.
Amy J Berg's portrait of Janis Joplin is moving and well researched - a cautionary tale of a rock star cut down in her prime.

This teen horror fantasy (based on RL Stine's bestselling children's books) is made with an anarchic glee that, in its better moments, rekindles memories of Joe Dante's zany, tongue-in-cheek movies of the 1980s.
The film itself is very uneven. Any texture, depth and pathos here resides in the central performance.

For all the creakiness of its plotting, this is a Marvel adaptation mercifully shorn of bombast. There is far more bite in its humour than in last year's Ant-Man. Reynolds plays the lead role in an enjoyably freewheeling fashion.
King Jack isn't breaking new ground in its subject matter but it is an exceptional piece of film-making - one of the very best debut features of its type since David Gordon Green's George Washington.

Despite its production values, the film plays like a 1990s Comic Strip Presents spoof. It is lively and entertaining early on but once we get accustomed to its strange mix of gentility and blood-letting, the magic dissipates.

The film makes its hedonistic protagonists seem like characters in a classical tragedy. The intimacy between them becomes more oppressive and results in ever more extreme behaviour. The zest of the film-making belies the darkness at the core here.
Eli Roth's cannibal horror movie has its full quota of gore, but this is much more than an exploitation pic.

It's a very entertaining yarn made all the more enjoyable by the fact the band's two leading members, guitarist Jay Jay French and his arch rival, lead singer Dee Snider, have a very well-developed sense of their own absolute ridiculousness.
In its depiction of physical pain, the film rekindles memories both of Bergman's Cries And Whispers and of the death scene in Davies's own Distant Voices, Still Lives.
It's then sheer glee off the comic set-pieces that enables Grimsby to transcend its preposterous plotting.
The Spanish director Alvaro Longoria's documentary about North Korea is startling, comical and often horrifying but very even-handed.
What is being released is a baffling hodge-podge of a movie, full of contradictory elements. Bits of it, seen in isolation, are effective and atmospheric, but the plotting is tangled and confused.
The suspicion lingers that this story might have been better told in a documentary than in a dramatic feature. The film also pulls its punches at times.
This celebration of Dad's Army surpasses the original.
This belated sequel turns out to be very heavy going.
The film is shot in very dark hues, as if the story doesn't warrant any brightness or colour. It is brilliantly acted and has a real, if very seedy, pathos about it.
Intriguing and provocative.
X-Men Apocalypse is a mind-bending trip of a movie, one likely both to exhilarate spectators and to leave many either with severe feelings of sensory overload or scratching their heads.
After his intimate, generation-spanning epic Boyhood, Richard Linklater is back with an equally special and magical film, albeit one with a much tighter focus.
Our Kind Of Traitor is an entertaining but very lightweight espionage thriller with none of the seedy pathos of the older films.
A gentle and whimsical romantic comedy-drama.
At 80, though, the director hasn't lost his knack for telling stories about marginalised characters with wit, anger and humanity.
For all its longueurs, it is a rich and rewarding reworking of the road movie genre -- a film that is as original as it is exasperating.
Frears' biopic is both sly and affecting.
For all its technical excellence and surrealistic flights of fancy, this isn't Spielberg at full throttle.
Hanks is often cast as the dependable American everyman type. Here, he shows a darker, more anxious side to that character. It is one of his richest recent performances.
This is a dour three-hander, set on a remote Scottish island in the 1940s.
Tarkovsky pays full attention to the squalor and pity of war but never loses his sense of poetry.
Nothing if not original, this is almost certainly the only movie about a terrier that cites the writing of Wittgenstein and Kierkegaard, the painting of Goya and the wisdom of Jewish grandmothers.
What the film makes apparent isn't just Hockney's dandyism and brilliance, but also his formidable work ethic.
Love & Friendship is an unexpected delight, a very dry and tremendously witty adaptation of a little known Jane Austen novella.
Money Monster is entertaining enough as a thriller. It is also strangely undercharged and lacking in ambition given the talent behind it.
For at least half its running length Sing Street is tremendous: a coming of age story set in early 80s Dublin that has the comic poignance and truthfulness of a Gregory's Girl or a Son Rambow.
The action sequences, like everything else in the film, are extremely stylishly shot but there is so much posturing going on that the film is utterly shorn of drama or tension.
I Saw The Light gives us an exceptional central performance -- but one that is entombed in a very dull and listless film.
A movie that yields line like 'unfriend this dead bitch' has a certain camp appeal but this is an unpleasant and manipulative affair that makes increasingly grim viewing.
It may serve up exactly the same mix of mayhem, noodles and dumplings as the first two films in the series, but Kung Fu Panda 3 is still energetic and wildly entertaining fare.
The genius of the film lies in its combination of traditional Disney characters and situations with a very subversive storytelling style.

Cousins doesn't ignore the bloodshed and sectarian violence (the pub bombings, the killings, the evictions) in the city's recent past but he also has a genius for finding the poetry and humour in everyday street scenes.
This is a film that draws you in even as it perplexes you and that ultimately has a very strong emotional kick.
This may appear the typical buttoned up British costume drama but, in its own understated way, it is both acutely observed and very moving.
It is dismaying to see actors off the quality of Chastain, Theron and Blunt mugging it up in such caricatured and poorly written roles.
A searing and brilliant film is only partly undermined by its wildly improbable, action movie style ending in which the lead character rediscovers his inner Rambo.
The Bridesmaids-style bawdiness is still there but the characters haven't developed or grown up in the slightest.

The latest attempt to bring Rudyard Kipling's Mowgli to the screen is a triumph - a painstakingly crafted digital 3D movie whose astonishing visual effects are complemented by very sure-footed storytelling and tremendous voice-work.
For all its invocations of Russian history, this is a glorified telenovela at heart.
As the bushy haired Russian filmmaker, Elmer Bäck looks and behaves like Harpo Marx. It's an intriguing performance which captures its subject's humour, prurience and his visionary qualities.
What's refreshing, though, is how nuanced the film's approach remains. There is no simple minded resolution here and it is inevitable that there will be blood on somebody's hands by the final reel.
Davis's behaviour is monstrous but Cheadle plays him with such charisma that he seems perversely sympathetic anyway. We root for him.
Bastille Day is a cheesy but enjoyable Paris set thriller which underlines Idrs Elba's fast rising credentials as an action hero.

This was a troubled production. Scottish director Lynne Ramsay quit days before shooting began and there were late changes made to the cast. In certain respects, the replacement director Gavin O'Connor has done an impressive job.
'He wanted to be a legend,' we are told again and again - and the filmmakers show just how single-mindedly he set about becoming one.
The result is an American movie dressed up in British clothes that simply don't fit.
The account of Moore's untimely death, aged only 51, can't help but bring a lump to the throat.
There are a few moments of hilarity, but most of the film seems merely grotesque. It's baffling as to what draws De Niro to such material when he should be playing Willy Loman or King Lear.
All its devices and ironic references could easily have made the film seem forbidding, but it has an unlikely emotional impact.
It is lines such as "Men can survive without love but not us women" that make this film such a stinker.
Thanks to the richness of Maggie Smith's performance, a cantankerous bigot who leaves shit and chaos in her wake ends up seeming a tragic heroine, far more sinned against than sinning.
This is virtuoso film-making only partially let down by its artifice.

There are a few too many tourist-eye views of the spectacular Kenyan landscapes and the animation is a distraction. Warriors, though, has a warmth and humour that a more polemical documentary on the same subject would surely have lacked.
The "bad fairies" lurking within have the ability to stretch their roots and branches round car engines and baby's cots. The problem is that the plotting gets lost amid all the foliage.
Tangerine is a bit of a marvel, a low-budget film reportedly shot entirely on the iPhone 5 but one which combines extraordinary visual inventiveness, humour and pathos.
Gaspar Noé's brave but wildly misguided film is an attempt to make a movie depicting "sexual sentimentality". It is graphic and not above prurient shock tactics.
This is probably the most insightful film about the life of a footballer off the pitch since Vikash Dhorasoo's Substitute.
Jocelyn Moorhouse's latest feature is lively and enjoyable enough, and often gorgeous to look at, but undermined by its shifting storytelling styles.
Maurice Jarre's music is as beguiling as ever and Lean squeezes all the pathos that he can out of the romance between Sharif's Yuri Zhivago and Julie Christie's febrile and gorgeous Lara Antipova.
The film has plenty of magnificently shot footage of the horses galloping across the landscapes.
This is a small-scale but delicately crafted and moving family drama, lent an extra resonance by the fact that it features the final performance from Richard Johnson, who died in June.

It is attractively performed by its leads and sometimes very funny, with several scenes of lovers being caught in flagrante or hiding from one another, but is undermined by its very contrived and all too predictable plotting.
movie_title: All About Them (A Trois, On Y Va) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is a Christmas film with an enjoyably barbed edge.

The anonymous performers from so long ago show both bravery and, often, startling balletic grace. It's very eerie to watch. Many of the routines involving animals and humans alike are based around cruelty, humiliation and extreme danger.
This grimly fascinating doc, made for the website VICE, looks at the way synthetic drug use in London's gay community has rocketed, mirrored by the HIV-positive rate.
There is real poignancy here in the reminiscences of McQueen's former wife Neile Adams and his son, Chad. Like the Le Mans movie itself, the doc sometimes loses its focus but it is beautifully made.
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Night Before pretends to be an anti-Christmas Christmas film but, for all the bad behaviour of its three male leads, ends up just as gloopy and manipulative as any of the other seasonal movies released this year.

Bradley Cooper and Sienna Miller, reunited on screen after last year's American Sniper, give committed and likeable performances but battle against the sheer contrivances and strange mix of ingredients in an over-egged screenplay.

Malala Yousafzai is a truly inspirational figure, a teenager who won the Nobel Peace Prize while still studying for her GCSEs in Birmingham, but she isn't especially well-served by Davis Guggenheim's reverential documentary about her.
Mississippi Grind is a rarity: an American movie about gambling that actually acknowledges that when you stay up all night in a badly lit room, your skin is likely to become very clammy and blotchy.
The Last Witch Hunter is an unwieldy mishmash, pitched between sword-and-sorcery epic and modern-day action movie.

Steve Jobs is successful in conveying the excitement verging on hysteria that each new launch provoked. It deals very skilfully with the ups and downs in Jobs' career -- his wilderness years after he left Apple and his glorious return.
A Second Coming is likely to leave audiences with a mixture of admiration for and baffled exasperation with its subject.
Combining archive footage and present-day interviews, and using music to drive the story, Nelson tells a complicated and often violent story in lithe, inventive fashion.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Moving and revelatory.
Ed Oxenbould, the talented Aussie child actor also recently seen in The Visit, gives another appealing performance in this otherwise bland and flimsy kids' movie.
As zombies' heads are shot off and feral cats and even more feral old ladies prey on the hapless adolescent heroes, you can't help but warm to the cheery irreverence of the storytelling.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [The film] seems light-hearted and even whimsical at times but its director is making very serious points about the repressive nature of Iranian society.
The breezy and humorous tone doesn't disguise the fact that Thorpe's film is both intimate and quietly courageous.
The plot may seem familiar from dozens of other Mafia movies but what is original here is the film's mournful tone and its absolute refusal to glamorize violence in any way.
It may not be the recommendation that [Kevin Allen] is looking for but this is a film you can watch with your eyes closed and still enjoy.
The fascination of Fresh Dressed lies in the inventive and revealing way it interweaves politics, music and sociology. This, it turns out, is much more than just a documentary about fashion.
This is by far the darkest, most violent entry in the series, but also the best.
The film's redeeming factor is its giddy sense of excess. Like the protagonist of The Wolf of Wall Street, Stelfox pushes everything to absolute extremes.
Saoirse Ronan, who must be among the front-runners for the Best Actress Oscar, gives a remarkable performance as Eilis Lacey, a young woman who moves from small-town Ireland to New York.
In terms of characterisation and plotting, the film is utterly absurd, but taken as a fairground ride for the ghoulishly inclined, it just about passes muster.
The film is far too flighty to allow its actors to bring much depth or pathos to their characters.
The biggest disappointment is the waste of such an excellent cast. This is terminally treacly fare in which the writing is often very trite indeed.
Taken as a lurid, B-movie-style pantomime fantasy, the film is quite fun but it is vexing to see actors of the calibre of McAvoy and Radcliffe reduced to such abject mugging.
Kleiman has an eye for poetic imagery but the storytelling style is so oblique and dour that this is a jarring and difficult film to watch.
If you can stomach the schmaltz and suspend your disbelief in the face of the film's pounding predictability, you'll find plenty to enjoy.
Room offers highly imaginative and, at times, visionary film-making that transcends its claustrophobic settings and defies genre stereotyping.
Ip Man 3 is a more prosaic and workmanlike affair, albeit with some very elegant fight scenes and an enjoyable cameo from the former world heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson.
[A] creaky, low-budget exploitation thriller.
It becomes increasingly dreary and derivative - and ends in a way that suggests several more mind-numbing sequels will soon be washing over us.
Adam McKay's raucous comedy... manages the unlikely feat of being wildly entertaining while telling a complex and ultimately depressing story.
The film may not fill you with admiration for Filin himself, who is a charismatic but very divisive figure, but it certainly induces a sense of awe about the work of the company itself.
This is a horribly stodgy and misconceived attempt to make a modern-day New York-set equivalent to It's A Wonderful Life.
The film, overall, is fatally uncertain of its identity - never quite certain whether it's a gruesome murder-mystery out to shock us or a heavy, character-based drama about a family torn apart.
The director pays exhaustive attention to sound editing and mise-en-scène.
It's an inspiring story, very well told by the directors of McCullin.
movie_title: Attacking The Devil: Harold Evans And The Last Nazi War Crime (2014)

movie_review_blurb: McCarthy is dealing with grim subject matter but the film has the momentum of a well-told detective thriller.
It's undeniably spectacular in its own juddering, pyrotechnical, Armageddon-ish fashion, but it's also a film that leads a very rancid taste.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Riggen's account... is more thoughtful than the average disaster movie.
It's a feeble storyline and the film is only partially lifted by some lively action sequences and one or two Gravity-like scenes of the astronauts drifting in space.
The film is likeable but nowhere near as sharp or as funny as you hope it is going to be.
At its best, the new film is the equal of its predecessor. [Distant Voice, Still Lives] The first half in particular has extraordinary visual grace.
It works both as a war movie and, in its latter scenes, as a finely calibrated courtroom drama.

Writer-director Headland's screenplay is sharply observed in places and yields a few memorable set pieces (including a brawl in a restaurant that shocks a pregnant woman into going into labour.) It is also utterly predictable in its plotting.
It is a mad, visionary and quite often preposterous survival tale, very bloody, very violent and full of murky religious symbolism. It is also often astounding in its flights of macabre lyricism.
This documentary about Ol' Blue Eyes has a rough-and-ready quality, as if it has been rushed toward completion in time for Frank Sinatra's centenary.
It's an exercise in high kitsch which enraptures at first, but becomes increasingly enervating the longer it lasts.
This Scottish-made "swingers" film, based on a novel by Ewan Morrison, has some intriguing elements but is undermined by its shifts in tone and approach.
What makes Sisters seem so fresh and funny, in spite of its recycling of old gross-out gags, is the sly wit of Paula Pell's screenplay.
Immordino Vreeland tells [Peggy Guggenheim's] story in a lively way, combining gossip, name-dropping and frothier elements with a serious appraisal of her contribution to art history.
Grandma is a gem of a film with a very abrasive edge.
The miracle here is that for all its use of irony and self-reflexive devices, Le Mepris still ends up with a considerable emotional punch.
By the Sea, Angelina Jolie Pitt's latest feature as director, is a strangely torpid and paradoxical affair.

The self-effacing Charlie is the antithesis of the typical American movie hero. The film is charming and whimsical but makes some very trenchant points about the grimmer side of an all-American childhood.
A film that fans of the old movies will relish but one that looks bound to capture the imagination of a new audience, too.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There is bad faith on all sides but, amid all the bickering about money and safety, Peedom always also pays attention to the courage and selflessness of her subjects.
In lithe, lyrical fashion, Jacquet combines archive footage of the scientist's early trips to Antarctica with newly shot material.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Howard seems caught in some no-man's land between the poetic force of Melville's novel and the discursive academic approach of Philbrick.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell, though, has a genuinely subversive quality as a comedian. He looks and seems bland in the extreme but his behaviour is frequently outrageous.
The latest feature from writer-director David O. Russell is a quirky but very perceptive comedy-drama made in Russell's usual freewheeling style.

At 188 minutes, The Hateful Eight may seem absurdly long given its relative lack of incident but with dialogue and performances as fine as they are here, the film doesn't outstay its welcome in the slightest.

As drama, this is downbeat and depressive but Stone elicits committed and intense performances from an excellent cast and his low-key naturalistic approach is at least occasionally leavened by moments of lyricism.
In the end, though, in spite of its hard-hearted cynical veneer, David Gordon Green's comedy-drama turns into a strangely soft-centred and manipulative affair.
There's lots of noise and mayhem but this is glorified kids' matinee fare at heart. It's a pity to see an actress as accomplished as Laura Linney reduced to playing the Commissioner Gordon-like role.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Two fine actors giving full-blooded performances can't prevent Swiss Army Man from seeming pretentious and self-indulgent.
Blunt throws herself into her role as the tormented heroine. It's the kind of masochistic part that Joan Crawford would have relished in an earlier era.
A United Kingdom is a very likeable film about two very admirable people.
This crafty, enjoyable and illuminating documentary comes at the Church Of Scientology from an unexpected angle.
The Guv'nor is very uneven and looks as if it was made quickly and cheaply, but it offers a perspective on Lenny that goes beyond the caricature of the lovable East End "hard man".
Gibson is only 60 years old, a few years younger than Liam Neeson, and so could conceivably continue appearing in action movies like this for years to come. He clearly has the knack for it.
War On Everyone is more a series of comic sketches than it is a coherent movie.
Hanks is a very fine actor but Langdon is one of his most thankless roles.
You admire the diligence and thoughtfulness of the director and the actress but you still doubt their motives.
The visual ingenuity is breathtaking.
What has started as a pared-down and brutal thriller turns into a family melodrama.
It is a thoroughly heartwarming story in which you're rooting so hard for the heroine that you scarcely notice how contrived some of Nair's dramatic gambits really are.
With so much going on, it is little wonder that the film seems so sprawling and unfocused.
Made in iridescent colour, Trolls is a wondrously zany and inane animated feature. Watching it in 3D is like being submerged in candy floss.
Keeping Up With The Joneses is a misconceived comedy-thriller that can't work out whether it's spoofing spy movies or making fun of suburbia.
Free State Of Jones is an American Civil War-era saga that would surely have worked better as a box set TV drama than as a feature film. There is just too much information to pack in.
